original: Indeed she’s a most fresh and delicate creature.
modern: Yes, she’s young and tender.

original: What an eye she has! Methinks it sounds a parley to provocation.
modern: And such pretty eyes! Like an invitation.

original: An inviting eye, and yet methinks right modest.
modern: Yes, she’s pretty. But she’s modest and ladylike too.

original: She is indeed perfection.
modern: She’s a perfect woman, it’s true.

original: Well, happiness to their sheets! Come, lieutenant, I have a stoup of wine, and here without are a brace of Cyprus gallants that would fain have a measure to the health of black Othello.
modern: Well, good luck to them tonight in bed! Come with us, lieutenant. I’ve got a jug of wine, and these two Cyprus gentlemen want to drink a toast to the black Othello.

original: Not tonight, good Iago. I have very poor and unhappy brains for drinking. I could well wish courtesy would invent some other custom of entertainment.
modern: Not tonight, Iago. I’m not much of a drinker. I wish there was less social pressure to drink.

original: Oh, they are our friends. But one cup. I’ll drink for you.
modern: Oh, but these are our friends. Just one glass. I’ll do most of the drinking for you.

original: What, man, ’tis a night of revels! The gallants desire it.
modern: What are you talking about, man? Tonight is for celebrating! The gentlemen are waiting.

original: Where are they?
modern: Where are they?

original: Here at the door. I pray you call them in.
modern: By the door. Please invite them in.

original: I’ll do ’t, but it dislikes me.
modern: I’ll do it, but I don’t like it.

original: With that which he hath drunk tonight already, He’ll be as full of quarrel and offense As my young mistress' dog. Now my sick fool Roderigo, Whom love hath turned almost the wrong side out, Potations pottle-deep, and he’s to watch. Three lads of Cyprus, noble swelling spirits (That hold their honors in a wary distance, The very elements of this warlike isle) And they watch too. Now ’mongst this flock of drunkards Am I to put our Cassio in some action That may offend the isle. But here they come. If consequence do but approve my dream
modern: If I can just get him to drink one more glass after what he’s drunk already, he’ll be as argumentative and eager to fight as a little dog. That fool Roderigo, all twisted up inside with love, has been drinking toasts to Desdemona by the gallon, and he’s on guard duty.I’ve gotten the rest of the guards drunk, as well as several gentlemen from Cyprus who are quick to take offense. Now I’ll get Cassio to do something in front of all these drunkards that will offend everyone on the island. Here they come. If the future turns out as I hope it will, I’m all set for success.

original: 'Fore heaven, they have given me a rouse already.
modern: My God, they’ve given me a lot to drink.

original: Good faith, a little one, not past a pint, As I am a soldier.
modern: No, it was a little one, not more than a pint.

original: Some wine, ho! (sings)  And let me the cannikin clink, clink,  A soldier’s a man,  A life’s but a span,  Why then let a soldier drink.  Some wine, boys!
modern: Bring in more wine! (he sings)  And clink your glasses together,  And clink your glasses together.  A soldier’s a man,  And a man’s life is short,  So let the soldier drink.  Have some more wine, boys!

original: I learned it in England where indeed they are most potent in potting. Your Dane, your German, and your swag-bellied Hollander—Drink, ho!—are nothing to your English.
modern: I learned it in England, where they have a talent for drinking. The Danes, the Germans, and the Dutch—come on, drink, drink!—are nothing compared to the English.

original: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?
modern: Are Englishmen really such heavy drinkers?

original: Why, he drinks you with facility your Dane dead drunk; he sweats not to overthrow your Almain. He gives your Hollander a vomit ere the next pottle can be filled.
modern: They drink Danes under the table, and it takes them no effort at all to out-drink Germans. And the Dutch are vomiting while the English are asking for refills.

original: To the health of our general!
modern: Let’s drink to our general!

original: Oh, sweet England! (sings) King Stephen was a worthy peer, His breeches cost him but a crown, With that he called the tailor lown. He was a wight of high renown, And thou art but of low degree, 'Tis pride that pulls the country down, Some wine, ho!
modern: Oh, sweet England! (he sings)  King Stephen was a good king, and his pants were very cheap,  But he thought his tailor overcharged him, so he called him a peasant.  And that was a man of noble rank, much higher than you are.  So be happy with your worn-out cloak,  Since pride is ruining the nation.  More wine!

original: Why, this is a more exquisite song than the other.
modern: God, that song’s even better than the other one.

original: Will you hear ’t again?
modern: Do you want to hear it again?

original: No, for I hold him to be unworthy of his place that does those things. Well, heaven’s above all, and there be souls must be saved, and there be souls must not be saved.
modern: No, because we shouldn’t be doing that—stuff. Oh well, God’s in charge, and some people have to go to heaven, while other people have to go to hell.

original: For mine own part, no offence to the general nor any man of quality, I hope to be saved.
modern: Speaking for myself—and no offense to the general or anyone else—I hope I’m going to heaven.

original: And so do I too, lieutenant.
modern: Me too, lieutenant.

original: Ay, but (by your leave) not before me. The lieutenant is to be saved before the ancient. Let’s have no more of this, let’s to our affairs.—Forgive us our sins!—Gentlemen, let’s look to our business. Do not think, gentlemen, I am drunk. This is my ancient, this is my right hand, and this is my left. I am not drunk now. I can stand well enough, and I speak well enough.
modern: Okay, but please not before me. The lieutenant has to get to heaven before the ensign. But let’s stop this drinking and get down to business.—God forgive our sins!—Gentlemen, let’s get down to business. By the way, I don’t want anyone thinking I’m drunk. This is my ensign. This is my right hand, and this is my left hand. I’m not drunk. I can stand well enough, and I can speak just fine.

original: Excellent well!
modern: Yes, you’re speaking very well.

original: To th' platform, masters. Come, let’s set the watch.
modern: Let’s go to the platform where we’ll stand guard. Come on.

original: You see this fellow that is gone before, He is a soldier fit to stand by Caesar And give direction. And do but see his vice, The one as long as th' other. 'Tis pity of him. I fear the trust Othello puts him in On some odd time of his infirmity Will shake this island.
modern: You see that man who just left? He’s a good soldier, good enough to be Caesar’s right-hand man. But he has a serious weakness. It’s too bad. I’m worried that Othello trusts him too much, and it’ll be bad for Cyprus eventually.

original: But is he often thus?
modern: But is he often like this?

original: He’ll watch the horologe a double set If drink rock not his cradle.
modern: He drinks like this every night before he goes to sleep. He’d stay up all night and all day if he didn’t drink himself to sleep.

original: It were well The general were put in mind of it. Perhaps he sees it not, or his good nature And looks not on his evils. Is not this true?
modern: The general should be informed about this. Maybe he’s never noticed, or he only wants to see Cassio’s good side. Don’t you think so?

original: (aside) How now, Roderigo? I pray you, after the lieutenant, go!
modern: (speaking so that only RODERIGO can hear) Hello, Roderigo. Please, follow the lieutenant. Hurry! Go!

original: And ’tis great pity that the noble Moor With one of an ingraft infirmity. It were an honest action to say So to the Moor.
modern: And it’s too bad that the Moor chose a man with such a deep-rooted drinking problem as his second-in-command. We should definitely say something to the Moor.

original: Not I, for this fair island. I do love Cassio well, and would do much
modern: I wouldn’t say anything, not if you gave me the whole island for doing so. I respect Cassio and I’d like to help cure his alcoholism—

original: But, hark! What noise?
modern: What’s that noise?

original: Zounds! You rogue! You rascal!
modern: Damn you, you villain, you rascal!

original: What’s the matter, lieutenant?
modern: What’s the matter, lieutenant?

original: A knave teach me my duty?
modern: To think that fool had the nerve to try to teach me manners! I’ll beat him until the welts look like basket-weave!

original: Beat me?
modern: You’ll beat me?

original: Dost thou prate, rogue? (strikes him)
modern: Are you talking, you villain?(he hits RODERIGO)

original: Nay, good lieutenant! I pray you, sir, hold your hand. (stays him)
modern: No, don’t hit him, lieutenant! Please, sir, restrain yourself. (he restrains CASSIO)

original: Let me go, sir, or I’ll knock you o'er the mazzard.
modern: Let me go, or I’ll knock you on the head.

original: Drunk?
modern: Drunk?

original: (aside to RODERIGO) Away, I say, go out, and cry a mutiny.—
modern: (speaking so that only RODERIGO can hear) Go tell everyone there’s a riot.—

original: Nay, good lieutenant! Alas, gentlemen— Help, masters!—Here’s a goodly watch indeed!
modern: No, lieutenant—God, gentlemen—Help—Lieutenant—sir, Montano—Help, men!—The night guard is coming!

original: Who’s that which rings the bell?—Diablo, ho! The town will rise. Fie, Fie, lieutenant, You’ll be ashamed for ever.
modern: Who’s sounding that alarm? The whole town will riot! God, lieutenant, please stop! You’ll be ashamed of this forever!

original: I bleed still, I am hurt to the death. He dies!
modern: My God, I’m bleeding! I’ve been mortally wounded. I’ll kill him!

original: Hold, for your lives!
modern: Stop right now!

original: Hold, ho! Lieutenant—sir, Montano—gentlemen, Hold! The general speaks to you. Hold, for shame!
modern: Stop! Lieutenant—sir, Montano—gentlemen! Have you forgotten your duty and your sense of decorum? Stop! The general is talking to you! Stop, for God’s sake!

original: Why, how now, ho! From whence ariseth this? Are we turned Turks? And to ourselves do that Which heaven hath forbid the Ottomites? He that stirs next to carve for his own rage Holds his soul light, he dies upon his motion. Silence that dreadful bell, it frights the isle From her propriety. What is the matter, masters?— Speak, who began this? On thy love, I charge thee.
modern: How did this all start? Have we all become as savage as the Turks, treating each other as badly as they would have treated us? For heaven’s sake, stop this savage brawl! The next man who swings his sword must not care about his life, because the instant he strikes, he dies. Stop that alarm from ringing, it’s scaring the islanders. What’s the matter here, gentlemen?—Honest Iago, you look upset. Speak up and tell me who started this. Answer me.

original: I do not know. Friends all but now, even now, In quarter, and in terms like bride and groom Divesting them for bed. And then, but now,
modern: I don’t know. We were all having fun until just a minute ago; we were as happy as a bride and groom taking off their clothes. But then the mood suddenly changed. It was as if something had driven the men insane and made them point their swords at one another. I don’t

original: Swords out, and tilting one at other’s breasts In opposition bloody. I cannot speak Any beginning to this peevish odds, And would in action glorious I had lost
modern: know what could have started this. I’d rather have lost my legs in battle than be a part of this!

original: How comes it, Michael, you are thus forgot?
modern: How did you manage to lose your self-control like this, Michael?

original: I pray you pardon me, I cannot speak.
modern: Please, excuse me, sir. I can’t speak.

original: Worthy Montano, you were wont be civil. The gravity and stillness of your youth In mouths of wisest censure. What’s the matter That you unlace your reputation thus And spend your rich opinion for the name Of a night-brawler? Give me answer to it.
modern: Montano, you’re supposed to be calm and collected. You’re famous for it. Wise people respect you. What in the world made you risk your reputation like this and become a street brawler? Tell me.

original: Your officer Iago can inform you, While I spare speech, which something now offends me, Of all that I do know. Nor know I aught By me that’s said or done amiss this night, And to defend ourselves it be a sin When violence assails us.
modern: Othello, I’ve been seriously hurt. Your officer Iago can tell you what happened. I should save my breath, since it hurts to talk. I didn’t do anything wrong that I know of, unless it was a sin to defend myself when someone attacked me.

original: Now, by heaven, My blood begins my safer guides to rule, And passion, having my best judgment collied,
modern: All right, now I’m starting to lose my cool. By God, if you don’t tell me what happened you’ll all suffer. Tell me how this fight began, who started it. Whoever is guilty, even if he were my twin brother, I swear I’m through with him. We’re in a town that’s just

original: Or do but lift this arm, the best of you Shall sink in my rebuke. Give me to know How this foul rout began, who set it on, And he that is approved in this offence, Shall lose me. What, in a town of war Yet wild, the people’s hearts brimful of fear, To manage private and domestic quarrel? In night, and on the court and guard of safety?
modern: avoided a war, everyone’s still on edge, and you’re getting into private fights while you’re supposed to be on guard duty? That’s unbelievably bad. Iago, who started it?

original: If partially affined or leagued in office Thou dost deliver more or less than truth Thou art no soldier.
modern: I know you’re close to Cassio, but if you diverge from the truth in any way, you’re not a true soldier.

original: Touch me not so near. I had rather have this tongue cut from my mouth Yet I persuade myself to speak the truth Shall nothing wrong him. This it is, general: Montano and myself being in speech, There comes a fellow crying out for help To execute upon him. Sir, this gentleman Steps in to Cassio and entreats his pause, Myself the crying fellow did pursue, Lest by his clamor—as it so fell out— Outran my purpose, and I returned then rather For that I heard the clink and fall of swords And Cassio high in oath, which till tonight I ne'er might say before. When I came back— At blow and thrust, even as again they were When you yourself did part them. More of this matter cannot I report.
modern: You’re hitting close to home there. I’d rather cut my tongue out of my mouth than say anything bad about Michael Cassio. But I don’t think it’ll hurt him to tell the truth. This is what happened, General. Montano and I were talking when a man came running, crying for help. Cassio was chasing him with his sword out, trying to kill the guy. This gentleman stopped Cassio and told him to put away his sword. I followed the guy who was crying for help, to keep him from scaring the public. But he was fast and outran me. When I got back, I heard the swords clinking and Cassio swearing. I’d never heard him swear before. They were nearly killing each other, as you saw when you pulled them apart. I can’t tell you anything else.

original: But men are men, the best sometimes forget. As men in rage strike those that wish them best, Yet surely Cassio, I believe, received From him that fled some strange indignity Which patience could not pass.
modern: But nobody’s perfect, and even the best man sometimes loses control and strikes out in rage. Cassio was wrong to hurt Montano, who was only trying to help him, but I’m sure the guy who ran away must have offended Cassio in some terrible way, and Cassio couldn’t let it pass.

original: I know, Iago, Making it light to Cassio. Cassio, I love thee But never more be officer of mine.—
modern: Iago, I know you’re fond of Cassio and are downplaying this for his benefit. Cassio, I love you, but you’re never again going to be one of my officers.—

original: Look, if my gentle love be not raised up! I’ll make thee an example.
modern: Look, you’ve woken my wife! I’ll make you an example for the others to learn from.

original: All’s well, sweeting, Come away to bed.—(to MONTANO) Sir, for your hurts Myself will be your surgeon. Lead him off.
modern: Everything’s fine, now, sweetheart. Go back to bed.— (to MONTANO) I’ll see to it personally that your wounds are treated. Lead him off.

original: Iago, look with care about the town Come, Desdemona, ’tis the soldiers' life To have their balmy slumbers waked with strife.
modern: Iago, go and calm down the townspeople.—Come with me, Desdemona. Unfortunately, it’s part of the soldier’s life to be woken up by trouble.

original: What, are you hurt, lieutenant?
modern: Are you hurt, lieutenant?

original: Ay, past all surgery.
modern: Yes, but no doctor can help me.

original: Reputation, reputation, reputation! Oh, I have lost my reputation! I have lost the immortal part of myself, and what remains is bestial. My reputation, Iago, my reputation!
modern: My reputation, my reputation! I’ve lost my reputation, the longest-living and truest part of myself! Everything else in me is just animal-like. Oh, my reputation, Iago, my reputation!

original: As I am an honest man, I thought you had received some bodily wound. There is more sense in that than in reputation. Reputation is an idle and most false imposition, oft got without merit and lost without deserving. You have lost no reputation at all unless you repute yourself such a loser. What, man, there are ways to recover the general again. You are but now cast in his mood, a punishment more in policy than in malice, even so as one would beat his offenseless dog to affright an imperious lion. Sue to him again and he’s yours.
modern: I swear I thought you meant you’d been hurt physically. Your physical health matters more than your reputation. A reputation is a useless and fake quality that others impose on us. You haven’t lost it unless you think you have. There are lots of ways to get on the general’s good side again. You’ve been discharged because he’s angry, and because he’s obliged to do so for policy reasons, not because he dislikes you. He’s got to beat up the weak to frighten the strong. Go to him, petition him. He’ll change his mind.

original: I will rather sue to be despised than to deceive so good a commander with so slight, so drunken, and so indiscreet an officer. Drunk? And speak parrot? And squabble? Swagger? Swear? And discourse fustian with one’s own shadow? O thou invisible spirit of wine, if thou hast no name to be known by, let us call thee devil!
modern: I’d rather ask him to hate me than ask such a good commander to accept such a worthless, drunk, stupid officer as myself. Drunk? Babbling senselessly? Squabbling? Swaggering? Swearing? Ranting and raving to my own shadow! Oh, wine is the devil!

original: What was he that you followed with your sword? What had he done to you?
modern: Who were you chasing with your sword? What did he do to you?

original: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is that possible?

original: I remember a mass of things, but nothing distinctly. A quarrel, but nothing wherefore. Oh, that men should put an enemy in their mouths to steal away their brains! That we should, with joy, pleasance revel and applause, transform ourselves into beasts!
modern: I remember a jumble of impressions, but nothing distinctly. I remember a fight, but not why we were fighting. Oh God, why do men drink and lose their minds? Why do we party until we’re like animals?

original: Why, but you are now well enough. How came you thus recovered?
modern: You seem all right now. How did you get better?

original: It hath pleased the devil drunkenness to give place to the devil wrath. One unperfectness shows me another, to make me frankly despise myself.
modern: My drunkenness went away when anger took over. One weakness led to another, to make me hate myself.

original: I will ask him for my place again, he shall tell me I am a drunkard. Had I as many mouths as Hydra, such an answer would stop them all. To be now a sensible man, by and by a fool, and presently a beast! Oh, strange! Every inordinate cup is unblessed and the ingredient is a devil.
modern: I’ll ask him for my position back again, and he’ll tell me I’m a drunk. Even if I had a whole bunch of mouths, I wouldn’t be able to answer that. I was a reasonable man, then I became a fool, and finally a beast! Oh, how strange! Every glass of liquor is damned, and the devil’s the main ingredient!

original: Come, come, good wine is a good familiar creature, if it be well used. Exclaim no more against it. And, good lieutenant, I think you think I love you.
modern: Come on now, wine is good for you, if you know how to use it. Don’t say anything bad about wine anymore. Lieutenant, I think you know I’m your friend.

original: I have well approved it, sir. I drunk!
modern: I know that, sir. Imagine, me, a drunk!

original: You or any man living may be drunk at a time, man. I tell you what you shall do. Our general’s wife is now the general. I may say so in this respect, for that he hath devoted and given up himself to the contemplation, mark, and denotement of her parts and graces. Confess yourself freely to her, importune her help to put you in your place again. She is of so free, so kind, so apt, so blessed a disposition, she holds it a vice in her goodness not to do more than she is requested. This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her to splinter, and, my fortunes against any lay worth naming, this crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.
modern: Any man can get drunk sometime. I’ll tell you what to do. Othello’s wife has a lot of influence now. He’s completely devoted to her. Go open your heart to her. Ask her to help you get back your position. She is so generous, kind, and ready to help that she thinks it’s wrong not to do everything she can, even more than she is asked to do. Ask her to help you heal the rift between her husband and you. I’d bet my lucky stars your problem will be forgotten, and your relationship will be stronger than ever.

original: I protest, in the sincerity of love and honest kindness.
modern: I’m helping you because I like and respect you.

original: I think it freely, and betimes in the morning I will beseech the virtuous Desdemona to undertake for me. I am desperate of my fortunes if they check me.
modern: I believe it completely. Early in the morning I’ll go visit Desdemona and plead my case. My situation is desperate.

original: You are in the right. Good night, lieutenant, I must to the watch.
modern: You’re doing the right thing. Good night, lieutenant. I’ve got to go to the guard tower.

original: Good night, honest Iago.
modern: Good night, honest Iago.

original: When this advice is free I give and honest, Probal to thinking and indeed the course To win the Moor again? For ’tis most easy Th' inclining Desdemona to subdue As the free elements. And then for her To win the Moor, were to renounce his baptism, All seals and symbols of redeemèd sin, His soul is so enfettered to her love, Even as her appetite shall play the god With his weak function. How am I then a villain To counsel Cassio to this parallel course, Directly to his good? Divinity of hell! They do suggest at first with heavenly shows As I do now. For whiles this honest fool Plies Desdemona to repair his fortune And she for him pleads strongly to the Moor,
modern: Who can say I’m evil when my advice is so good? That’s really the best way to win the Moor back again. It’s easy to get Desdemona on your side. She’s full of good intentions. And the Moor loves her so much he would renounce his Christianity to keep her happy. He’s so enslaved by love that she can make him do whatever she wants. How am I evil to advise Cassio to do exactly what’ll do him good? That’s the kind of argument you’d expect from Satan! When devils are about to commit their biggest sins they put on their most heavenly faces, just like I’m doing now. And while this fool is begging Desdemona to help him, and while she’s pleading his case to the Moor, I’ll poison the Moor’s ear against her,

original: That she repeals him for her body’s lust. And by how much she strives to do him good She shall undo her credit with the Moor. So will I turn her virtue into pitch That shall enmesh them all.
modern: hinting that she’s taking Cassio’s side because of her lust for him. The more she tries to help Cassio, the more she’ll shake Othello’s confidence in her. And that’s how I’ll turn her good intentions into a big trap to snag them all.

original: How now, Roderigo!
modern: Hello, Roderigo!

original: I do follow here in the chase not like a hound that hunts, but one that fills up the cry. My money is almost spent, I have been tonight exceedingly well cudgeled, and I think the issue will be I shall have so much experience for my pains. And so, with no money at all and a little more wit, return again to Venice.
modern: I’m totally worn out. My chase is too much for me. I’ve spent most of my money, and tonight I got beaten up. The upshot is that I’ve got a little more experience. So with no money, but a little more wisdom, I’m going back to Venice.

original: How poor are they that have not patience! What wound did ever heal but by degrees? And wit depends on dilatory time. Does’t not go well? Cassio hath beaten thee. And thou, by that small hurt, hath cashiered Cassio. Though other things grow fair against the sun, Content thyself awhile. In troth, ’tis morning. Pleasure and action make the hours seem short. Retire thee, go where thou art billeted. Away, I say, thou shalt know more hereafter.
modern: You’re a poor man if you’re this impatient! If you get hurt, does your wound heal immediately? No, it heals gradually. We achieve things with our intelligence, not by magic, and intelligent planning takes time. Aren’t things going well? Cassio’s beaten you up, but with that tiny sacrifice on your part, you got Cassio discharged! If we’re patient, we’ll be rewarded with the fruits of our labors. My God, it’s morning. All this excitement has made the time fly by. Go back to where you’re staying and go to sleep. Go on, I’m telling you. You’ll understand better later. Go.

original: Two things are to be done: My wife must move for Cassio to her mistress. I’ll set her on. Myself, the while, to draw the Moor apart And bring him jump when he may Cassio find Dull not device by coldness and delay.
modern: Now two things still need to be done. My wife has to help make Desdemona take Cassio’s side. I’ll put her on that. And I need to take the Moor aside right at the moment when Cassio’s talking to Desdemona, so he’ll see them together. Yes, that’s the way I’ll do it. Let’s not ruin a brilliant plan by being slow to act.

original: Masters, play here, I will content your pains. Something that’s brief, and bid “Good morrow, general.”
modern: Musicians, start playing here. I’ll pay you for your trouble. Play something short that will put the general in a good mood.

original: Why masters, have your instruments been in Naples, that they speak i' th' nose thus?
modern:
Your instruments all have a nasal twang. Have they been to  Naples
Naples was considered a likely place to contract syphilis, which eats away at the bridge of the nose.Naples?

original: How, sir? How?
modern: Excuse me?

original: Ay, marry, are they, sir.
modern: Yes, they are.

original: Oh, thereby hangs a tail.
modern: Oh, there’s the problem.

original: Whereby hangs a tale, sir?
modern: What’s the problem?

original: Marry sir, by many a wind instrument that I know. But, masters, here’s money for you, and the general so likes your music that he desires you, for love’s sake, to make no more noise with it.
modern: Anyone full of hot air is a problem. But here’s some money. The general likes your music a lot, but he asks you to stop playing now.

original: If you have any music that may not be heard, to ’t again. But, as they say, to hear music the general does not greatly care.
modern: If you’ve got any music that can’t be heard, then play that. But as I said, the general isn’t really in the mood to hear music now.

original: We have none such, sir.
modern: We don’t have any music that can’t be heard.

original: Then put up your pipes in your bag, for I’ll away. Go, vanish into air, away!
modern: Then pack up your instruments and go away. Go!

original: Dost thou hear, my honest friend?
modern: Do you hear, my friend?

original: Prithee, keep up thy quillets. There’s a poor piece of gold for thee. If the gentlewoman that attends the general’s wife be stirring, tell her there’s one Cassio entreats her a little favour of speech. Wilt thou do this?
modern: Please don’t play games. (CASSIO gives CLOWN money). There’s a bit of gold for you. When the woman taking care of the general’s wife wakes up, could you please tell her that Cassio asks to speak with her?

original: She is stirring, sir. If she will stir hither, I shall seem to notify unto her.
modern: She’s awake, sir. If she feels like coming over here, I’ll give her your message.

original: In happy time, Iago.
modern: Good to see you, Iago.

original: You have not been abed, then?
modern: You didn’t go to sleep, then?

original: Why, no. The day had broke Before we parted. I have made bold, Iago, Is that she will to virtuous Desdemona Procure me some access.
modern: No. When I left you it was already morning. I’ve been bold, Iago. I’ve asked to talk to your wife. I’m going to ask her to let me talk to Desdemona.

original: I’ll send her to you presently, And I’ll devise a mean to draw the Moor May be more free.
modern: I’ll send her out to you now. I’ll think of a plan to get the Moor out of the way, so you can speak more openly.

original: I humbly thank you for’t.
modern: I humbly thank you.

original: I never knew a Florentine more kind and honest.
modern:
Even for a  Florentine
The citizens of Florence (who included Machiavelli) were not known for kindness and honesty, but Michael Cassio seems unaware of Florence’s bad reputation.Florentine, I never knew someone so kind and honest.

original: Good morrow, good Lieutenant. I am sorry The general and his wife are talking of it, And she speaks for you stoutly. The Moor replies That he you hurt is of great fame in Cyprus And great affinity, and that in wholesome wisdom And needs no other suitor but his likings To take the safest occasion by the front To bring you in again.
modern: Good morning, lieutenant. I’m sorry about what happened, but I’m sure everything will turn out all right. The general and his wife are talking about it now, and she’s defending you strongly. The Moor says the man you hurt is very important in Cyprus, and that under the circumstances he has no choice but to refuse to reinstate you. But he says he still loves and respects you, and based on his own feelings alone he’s looking for an opportunity to safely take you back.

original: Yet I beseech you, If you think fit, or that it may be done, With Desdemona alone.
modern: Please find a way to give me some time alone with Desdemona, if you think that’s all right.

original: Pray you come in. I will bestow you where you shall have time To speak your bosom freely.
modern: Please come in. I’ll take you to a place where you can speak freely.

original: I am much bound to you.
modern: Thank you very much.

original: These letters give, Iago, to the pilot, And by him do my duties to the senate. That done, I will be walking on the works, Repair there to me.
modern:
Iago, give these letters to the ship’s captain who
                                brought me here, and ask him to pay my respects to the Senate of
                                Venice. Now that’s done, I’m going to walk on
                                the fortification walls. Look for me there when you come
                            back.

original: This fortification, gentlemen, shall we see ’t?
modern: Shall we go see this fortification, men?

original: We’ll wait upon your lordship.
modern: We’re at your service, my lord.

original: Be thou assured, good Cassio, I will do All my abilities in thy behalf.
modern: I’ll do everything I can for you, Cassio.

original: Good madam, do. I warrant it grieves my husband As if the cause were his.
modern: Please do, madam. My husband’s so upset about Cassio’s problem you’d think it was his own.

original: But I will have my lord and you again As friendly as you were.
modern: Your husband’s such a good man. Don’t worry, Cassio. I’m sure you and my husband will be as friendly as you were before.

original: Bounteous madam, Whatever shall become of Michael Cassio, He’s never anything but your true servant.
modern: My dear beautiful lady, whatever happens to Michael Cassio, he’ll always be your humble servant.

original: You have known him long, and be you well assured He shall in strangeness stand no farther off Than in a polite distance.
modern: I know that. Thank you. You’re my husband’s friend and you’ve known him a long time. I assure you the only reason he’s keeping away from you now is political.

original: Ay, but, lady, That policy may either last so long, Or breed itself so out of circumstances, That, I being absent and my place supplied, My general will forget my love and service.
modern: Yes, my lady. But those political considerations might last such a long time that the general will forget my love and service, especially if I’m gone and someone else has my job.

original: Do not doubt that. Before Emilia here If I do vow a friendship, I’ll perform it To the last article. My lord shall never rest, I’ll watch him tame and talk him out of patience.
modern: That’ll never happen. Emilia here will be my witness: I promise you that you’ll get your position back again. And if I promise to help someone, I do everything I can. My husband will never get a moment’s rest, I’ll keep him up at night talking about you until he runs out

original: His bed shall seem a school, his board a shrift, With Cassio’s suit. Therefore be merry, Cassio, For thy solicitor shall rather die Than give thy cause away.
modern: of patience. He will think that his bed has become a conference table for discussing your problem—he won’t be able to get away from it. I’ll bring up your name at every moment. So cheer up. I’m your advocate, and I’d rather die than give up on you.

original: Madam, here comes my lord.
modern: Madam, here comes your husband.

original: Madam, I’ll take my leave.
modern: Madam, I’d better leave now.

original: Why, stay and hear me speak.
modern: Why not stay and hear me talk to him?

original: Unfit for mine own purposes.
modern: No, madam. I’m very uncomfortable, and that won’t help my case.

original: Well, do your discretion.
modern: Well, do whatever you think best.

original: Ha! I like not that.
modern: Hey! I don’t like that.

original: What dost thou say?
modern: What did you say?

original: Was not that Cassio parted from my wife?
modern: Wasn’t that Cassio leaving my wife?

original: Cassio, my lord? No, sure, I cannot think it That he would steal away so guilty-like Seeing you coming.
modern: Cassio, my lord? No, I don’t think so. He wouldn’t sneak away looking so guilty when he saw you coming.

original: How now, my lord? I have been talking with a suitor here, A man that languishes in your displeasure.
modern: What’s this, my lord? I was talking to a petitioner here just now, someone who’s suffering from your anger.

original: Who is ’t you mean?
modern: Who do you mean?

original: Why, your lieutenant, Cassio. Good my lord, His present reconciliation take. For if he be not one that truly loves you, That errs in ignorance and not in cunning, I have no judgment in an honest face.
modern: Your lieutenant, Cassio. Oh, if I’ve got any influence over you at all, please patch things up with him. In my judgment, this man truly loves you, and his mistake was innocent rather than wicked. Please call him and tell him to come back here.

original: Went he hence now?
modern: Was that him just now?

original: Ay, sooth, so humbled That he hath left part of his grief with me To suffer with him. Good love, call him back.
modern: Yes. He feels so bad and humble that I feel bad along with him. My love, call him back in here.

original: But shall ’t be shortly?
modern: But will it be soon?

original: The sooner, sweet, for you.
modern: Very soon, because you want it.

original: Shall ’t be tonight at supper?
modern: Will it be tonight at supper?

original: No, not tonight.
modern: No, not tonight.

original: Tomorrow dinner, then?
modern: Then tomorrow at dinner?

original: I shall not dine at home, I meet the captains at the citadel.
modern: I won’t be eating dinner at home. I’ll be meeting the captains at the citadel.

original: On Tuesday noon, or night, or Wednesday morn. I prithee name the time, but let it not Exceed three days. In faith, he’s penitent, And yet his trespass, in our common reason Out of her best) is not, almost, a fault T' incur a private check. When shall he come? Tell me, Othello. I wonder in my soul What you would ask me that I should deny That came a-wooing with you, and so many a time, When I have spoke of you dispraisingly, Hath ta'en your part, to have so much to do To bring him in? Trust me, I could do much—
modern: Well then, tomorrow night, or Tuesday morning. Or Tuesday noon or at night, or Wednesday morning. Please just name a time, but don’t wait more than three days. He’s very sorry. His mistake was hardly worth punishing him for in the first place—though in wartime it is sometimes necessary to make examples out of even the best soldiers. So when should he come? Tell me, Othello. I can’t imagine you asking me for something and me telling you no or standing there muttering. Michael Cassio came with you when you were trying to win my love. Sometimes I’d criticize you to him, and he’d defend you. And now I have to make this big fuss about bringing him back? I swear, I could do so much—

original: I will deny thee nothing.
modern: Please, no more. He can come whenever he wants. I won’t refuse you anything.

original: Why, this is not a boon, 'Tis as I should entreat you wear your gloves, Or feed on nourishing dishes, or keep you warm, Or sue to you to do a peculiar profit Wherein I mean to touch your love indeed It shall be full of poise and difficult weight And fearful to be granted.
modern: Don’t act like you’re doing me a favor! This is like if I asked you to wear your gloves when it’s cold outside, or eat nutritious food, or do something that’s good for you. If I ever have to ask you for something that will put your luck to the test, it’ll be something difficult and terrible.

original: I will deny thee nothing! Whereon I do beseech thee, grant me this,
modern: I won’t deny you anything! But in return, please, do one thing for me: leave me alone for a little while.

original: Shall I deny you? No. Farewell, my lord.
modern: Would I ever deny you anything? No. Goodbye, my husband.

original: Farewell, my Desdemona. I’ll come to thee straight.
modern: Goodbye, my Desdemona. I’ll come see you right away.

original: Emilia, come.—Be as your fancies teach you. Whate'er you be, I am obedient.
modern: Come here, Emilia.—Do whatever you feel like doing, my husband, and I’ll obey you.

original: But I do love thee! And when I love thee not Chaos is come again.
modern: What a wonderful girl! God help me, I love you! And when I stop loving you, the universe will fall back into the chaos that was there when time began.

original: My noble lord—
modern: My noble lord—

original: What dost thou say, Iago?
modern: What is it, Iago?

original: Know of your love?
modern: When you were wooing Desdemona, did Michael Cassio know about it?

original: He did, from first to last. Why dost thou ask?
modern: Yes, he knew about it the whole time. Why do you ask?

original: But for a satisfaction of my thought,
modern: I was just curious. No reason.

original: Why of thy thought, Iago?
modern: Why are you curious, Iago?

original: I did not think he had been acquainted with her.
modern: I didn’t realize he knew her.

original: Oh, yes, and went between us very oft.
modern: Oh, yes. He carried messages back and forth between us very often.

original: Indeed?
modern: Oh, really?

original: Indeed? Ay, indeed! Discern’st thou aught in that?
modern: Oh, really? Yes, really. Do you see something wrong with that? Isn’t he an honest man?

original: Honest, my lord?
modern: Honest, my lord?

original: Honest, ay, honest.
modern: Honest, yes, honest.

original: My lord, for aught I know.
modern: As far as I know, sir.

original: What dost thou think?
modern: What are you thinking?

original: Think, my lord?
modern: Thinking, my lord?

original: As if there were some monster in thy thought Too hideous to be shown. Thou dost mean something. I heard thee say even now thou lik’st not that When Cassio left my wife. What didst not like? Of my whole course of wooing, thou cried’st “Indeed?” And didst contract and purse thy brow together As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain Some horrible conceit. If thou dost love me
modern: “Thinking, my lord?” My God, you keep repeating everything I say as if you were thinking something too horrible to say out loud. You’re thinking something. Just a minute ago I heard you say you didn’t like it when Cassio left my wife. What didn’t you like? And when I told you he was involved the whole time I was trying to get Desdemona, you were like, “Oh, really?” And then you frowned and wrinkled up your forehead as if you were imagining something horrible. If you’re my friend, tell me what you’re thinking.

original: My lord, you know I love you.
modern: My lord, you know I’m your friend.

original: I think thou dost. And for I know thou 'rt full of love and honesty And weigh’st thy words before thou giv’st them breath, For such things in a false disloyal knave Are tricks of custom, but in a man that’s just They are close dilations, working from the heart, That passion cannot rule.
modern: I think you are. And I know you’re full of love and honesty, and you think carefully before you speak. That’s why these pauses of yours frighten me. If some fool were withholding things from me, I wouldn’t think twice about it. If some lying, cheating villain acted like that, it would just be a trick. But when an honest man acts like that, you know he’s wrestling with bad thoughts and can’t help it.

original: For Michael Cassio,
modern: As for Michael Cassio, I think it would be safe for me to swear that he’s honest.

original: I think so too.
modern: I think so too.

original: Men should be what they seem, Or those that be not, would they might seem none!
modern: People should be what they appear to be. If they’re not honest, they shouldn’t look like they are!

original: Certain, men should be what they seem.
modern: Absolutely, people should be what they appear to be.

original: Why then I think Cassio’s an honest man.
modern: In that case, I think Cassio’s an honest man.

original: I prithee speak to me as to thy thinkings, As thou dost ruminate, and give thy worst of thoughts The worst of words.
modern: No, I think there’s more to this than you’re letting on. Please tell me what you’re thinking—even your worst suspicions.

original: Good my lord, pardon me, Though I am bound to every act of duty Utter my thoughts? Why, say they are vile and false, As where’s that palace whereinto foul things Sometimes intrude not? Who has that breast so pure Wherein uncleanly apprehensions With meditations lawful?
modern: Please don’t make me do that, sir. I have to obey all your orders, but surely I’m not obligated to reveal my deepest thoughts—even slaves aren’t expected to do that. You want me to say what I’m thinking? What if my thoughts are disgusting and wrong? Even good people think horrible things sometimes. Who is so pure that they never think a bad thought?

original: Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago, If thou but think’st him wronged and mak’st his ear A stranger to thy thoughts.
modern: You’re not being a good friend, Iago, if you even think your friend has been wronged and you don’t tell him about it.

original: I do beseech you, As, I confess, it is my nature’s plague To spy into abuses, and oft my jealousy Shapes faults that are not, that your wisdom, From one that so imperfectly conceits, Out of his scattering and unsure observance. It were not for your quiet nor your good,
modern: Please don’t ask me to tell you. I might be completely wrong. I have a bad tendency to be suspicious of people and to look too closely into what they’re doing. Often I imagine crimes that aren’t really there. You would be wise to ignore my weak guesses and imaginary suspicions, and don’t worry yourself about the meaningless things I’ve noticed. For me to tell you my thoughts would only destroy your peace of mind, and

original: Nor for my manhood, honesty, and wisdom To let you know my thoughts.
modern: it wouldn’t be wise, honest, or responsible for me to tell them.

original: What dost thou mean?
modern: What are you talking about?

original: Is the immediate jewel of their souls. Who steals my purse steals trash. 'Tis something, nothing: 'Twas mine, ’tis his, and has been slave to thousands. But he that filches from me my good name And makes me poor indeed.
modern: A good reputation is the most valuable thing we have—men and women alike. If you steal my money, you’re just stealing trash. It’s something, it’s nothing: it’s yours, it’s mine, and it’ll belong to thousands more. But if you steal my reputation, you’re robbing me of something that doesn’t make you richer, but makes me much poorer.

original: I’ll know thy thoughts.
modern: I’m going to find out what you’re thinking.

original: You cannot, if my heart were in your hand, Nor shall not, whilst ’tis in my custody.
modern: You can’t find that out, even if you held my heart in your hand you couldn’t make me tell you. And as long my heart’s inside my body, you never will.

original: Ha!
modern: What?

original: It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock The meat it feeds on. That cuckold lives in bliss Who, certain of his fate, loves not his wronger, But, oh, what damnèd minutes tells he o'er
modern: Beware of jealousy, my lord! It’s a green-eyed monster that makes fun of the victims it devours. The man who knows his wife is cheating on him is happy, because at least he isn’t friends with the man she’s sleeping with. But think of the unhappiness of a man who worships his wife, yet doubts her faithfulness. He suspects her, but still loves her.

original: Oh, misery!
modern: Oh, what misery!

original: Poor and content is rich, and rich enough, But riches fineless is as poor as winter To him that ever fears he shall be poor. From jealousy!
modern: The person who’s poor and contented is rich enough. But infinite riches are nothing to someone who’s always afraid he’ll be poor. God, help us not be jealous!

original: Why, why is this? Think’st thou I’d make a life of jealousy, To follow still the changes of the moon With fresh suspicions? No! To be once in doubt When I shall turn the business of my soul To such exsufflicate and blowed surmises, Matching thy inference. 'Tis not to make me jealous To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company, Where virtue is, these are more virtuous. Nor from mine own weak merits will I draw The smallest fear or doubt of her revolt, For she had eyes and chose me. No, Iago, And on the proof there is no more but this: Away at once with love or jealousy!
modern: Why are you telling me this? Do you think I would live a life of jealousy, tormented by new suspicions every hour? No. If there’s any doubt, there is no doubt. I might as well be a goat if I ever let myself become obsessed with the kind of suspicions you’re implying. If you say my wife is beautiful, eats well, loves good company, speaks freely, sings, plays music, and dances well, you’re not making me jealous. When a woman is virtuous, talents like these just make her better. And I’m not going to start feeling inferior. She had her eyes wide open when she chose me. No, Iago, I’ll have to see some real evidence before I start suspecting her of anything bad, and when I suspect her, I’ll look for proof, and if there’s proof, that’s when I’ll let go of my love and my jealousy.

original: I am glad of this, for now I shall have reason To show the love and duty that I bear you Receive it from me. I speak not yet of proof. Look to your wife, observe her well with Cassio. Wear your eyes thus, not jealous nor secure. I would not have your free and noble nature I know our country disposition well. In Venice they do let God see the pranks They dare not show their husbands. Their best conscience Is not to leave ’t undone, but keep’t unknown.
modern: I’m glad to hear you say that. Now I can show you my devotion and my duty with more honesty. So please listen to me. I’m not talking about proof yet. Watch your wife. Watch how she is with Cassio. Just watch—don’t be either completely suspicious or completely trustful. I wouldn’t want to see you taken advantage of because you’re such an open and trusting guy. Watch out! I know the people of Venice well. They let God see things they wouldn’t show their husbands. They don’t avoid doing things that are wrong, they just try not to get caught.

original: She did deceive her father, marrying you, And when she seemed to shake and fear your looks, She loved them most.
modern: She lied to her father to marry you. And when she pretended to be afraid of you, she loved you the most.

original: And so she did.
modern: That’s right, she did.

original: Why, go to then. She that, so young, could give out such a seeming, He thought ’twas witchcraft. But I am much to blame. I humbly do beseech you of your pardon For too much loving you.
modern: Well, there you go. She was so young, but she deceived her father so thoroughly he thought it was witchcraft! But I’m sorry I’ve blurted all this out. I beg your pardon for loving you too much.

original: I am bound to thee forever.
modern: I’m indebted to you forever.

original: I see this hath a little dashed your spirits.
modern: You seem a little depressed about this.

original: Trust me, I fear it has. I hope you will consider what is spoke Comes from my love. But I do see you’re moved. I am to pray you not to strain my speech To grosser issues nor to larger reach
modern: Really, I’m afraid you are. I hope you remember that I said all this because I love you. But I see you’re troubled. Please don’t take what I said more seriously than it deserves to be taken.

original: I will not.
modern: I won’t.

original: Should you do so, my lord, My speech should fall into such vile success Which my thoughts aimed not at. Cassio’s my worthy friend—
modern: If you take it too seriously, it’ll have bad effects that I didn’t want it to have. Cassio’s a good friend of mine—My lord, I can see you’re upset.

original: No, not much moved. I do not think but Desdemona’s honest.
modern: No, not too upset. I’m sure Desdemona would never cheat on me.

original: Long live she so. And long live you to think so.
modern: I hope she never does! And I hope you keep on thinking she wouldn’t.

original: And yet how nature, erring from itself—
modern: But still, it’s true that good things can go bad, away from their true natures—

original: Ay, there’s the point. As, to be bold with you, Of her own clime, complexion, and degree, Whereto we see in all things nature tends— Foh! One may smell in such a will most rank, Foul disproportions, thoughts unnatural. Distinctly speak of her, though I may fear Her will, recoiling to her better judgment, May fall to match you with her country forms, And happily repent.
modern: That’s the point I’m trying to make. If I can be frank with you, she veered away from her own nature in turning down all those young men from her own country, with her skin color, with her status—everything her nature would have drawn her to—Ugh! You can almost smell the dark and ugly desires inside her, the unnatural thoughts—But—I’m sorry—I didn’t mean to refer to her specifically just now. I only worry that she might snap back to her natural taste in men one day, and compare you unfavorably to other Italians.

original: Farewell, farewell. Set on thy wife to observe. Leave me, Iago.
modern: Goodbye, goodbye. If you see anything else, let me know. Tell your wife to watch her. Leave me alone now, Iago.

original: My lord, I take my leave. (going)
modern: My lord, I’ll say goodbye now. (beginning to exit)

original: (aside) Why did I marry? This honest creature doubtless Sees and knows more, much more, than he unfolds.
modern: (to himself) Why did I ever get married? I’m sure this good and honest man sees and knows more, much more, than he’s telling me.

original: To scan this thing no farther. Leave it to time. Although ’tis fit that Cassio have his place, For sure, he fills it up with great ability, Yet, if you please to hold him off awhile, Note if your lady strain his entertainment
modern: (returning) My lord, please don’t think about this any more. Time will tell. It’s right for Cassio to have his lieutenancy back—he’s very talented. But keep him away for a while, and you’ll see how he goes about getting it back. Notice whether your wife insists on your

original: With any strong or vehement importunity. Much will be seen in that. In the meantime, Let me be thought too busy in my fears— And hold her free, I do beseech your honor.
modern: giving it back to him. That will tell you a lot. But in the meantime, just assume that I’m paranoid—as I’m pretty sure I am—and keep thinking she’s innocent, please.

original: Fear not my government.
modern: Don’t worry about how I handle it.

original: I once more take my leave.
modern: I’ll say goodbye once more.

original: This fellow’s of exceeding honesty And knows all quantities, with a learnèd spirit, Though that her jesses were my dear heartstrings, I’d whistle her off and let her down the wind To prey at fortune. Haply, for I am black And have not those soft parts of conversation Into the vale of years—yet that’s not much— She’s gone, I am abused, and my relief Must be to loathe her. Oh, curse of marriage That we can call these delicate creatures ours And live upon the vapor of a dungeon Than keep a corner in the thing I love For others' uses. Yet ’tis the plague to great ones, Prerogatived are they less than the base. Even then this forkèd plague is fated to us When we do quicken. Look where she comes.
modern: This Iago is extremely honest and good, and he knows a lot about human behavior. If it turns out that she really is running around on me, I’ll send her away, even though it’ll break my heart. Maybe because I’m black, and I don’t have nice manners like courtiers do, or because I’m getting old—but that’s not much—She’s gone, and I’ve been cheated on. I have no choice but to hate her. Oh what a curse marriage is! We think our beautiful wives belong to us, but their desires are free! I’d rather be a toad in a moldy basement than to have only a part of someone I love, sharing the rest of her with others. This is the plague of important men—our wives betray us more than those of poor men. It’s our destiny, like death. We are destined to be betrayed when we are born. Oh, here she comes.

original: If she be false, heaven mocked itself. I’ll not believe ’t.
modern: If she’s cheated on me, then heaven itself is a fake. I don’t believe it.

original: How now, my dear Othello? By you invited, do attend your presence.
modern: What’s going on, Othello, darling? The nobles of Cyprus whom you invited to dinner are waiting for you.

original: I am to blame.
modern: I’m sorry.

original: Why do you speak so faintly? Are you not well?
modern: Why are you whispering? Are you sick?

original: Why that’s with watching, ’twill away again. Let me but bind it hard, within this hour It will be well. (pulls out a handkerchief)
modern: That’s from lack of sleep. It’ll go away. Let me wrap up your head, and it will feel okay in less than an hour. (she pulls out a handkerchief)

original: Your napkin is too little,
modern: No, your handkerchief’s too little. Leave my head alone.

original: Come, I’ll go in with you.
modern: Come on, I’ll escort you to dinner.

original: I am very sorry that you are not well.
modern: I’m very sorry you’re not feeling well.

original: (picks up the handkerchief) I am glad I have found this napkin, My wayward husband hath a hundred times
modern: (picking up the handkerchief) I’m glad I found this handkerchief. It’s the first keepsake the Moor gave her. My stubborn husband has asked me to steal it a

original: Wooed me to steal it, but she so loves the token (For he conjured her she should ever keep it) That she reserves it evermore about her And give ’t Iago. What he will do with it Heaven knows, not I. I nothing but to please his fantasy.
modern: hundred times. But she loves it so much (since Othello told her she should always keep it with her) that she always keeps it near her to kiss it and talk to it. I’ll copy the embroidery pattern and then give it to Iago. Heaven knows what he’s going to do with it. I only try to satisfy his whims.

original: How now! What do you here alone?
modern: What’s going on? What are you doing here alone?

original: A thing for me? It is a common thing—
modern:
You’ve got something for me? It’s a common 

thing
“Thing” was slang for vagina. By saying that Emilia’s “thing” is “common,” Iago implies that she lets anyone have sex with her

thing—

original: Ha?
modern: What?

original: To have a foolish wife.
modern: —to have a stupid wife.

original: Oh, is that all? What will you give me now
modern: Oh, is that so? And what would you give me for the handkerchief?

original: What handkerchief?
modern: What handkerchief?

original: What handkerchief? Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona, That which so often you did bid me steal.
modern: What handkerchief? The one the Moor gave to Desdemona, which you asked me to steal so many times.

original: No, but she let it drop by negligence And, to th' advantage, I being here, took ’t up. Look, here it is.
modern: No, actually. She dropped it carelessly, and, seizing the opportunity, since I was here, I picked it up. Look, here it is.

original: A good wench, give it me.
modern: Good girl, give it to me.

original: What will you do with ’t, that you have been so earnest
modern: And what are you going to do with it? Why did you want it so much that you begged me to steal it?

original: Why, what is that to you?
modern: What’s it to you?

original: If it be not for some purpose of import, Give ’t me again. Poor lady, she’ll run mad When she shall lack it.
modern: If you don’t need it for some important reason, then give it back to me. Poor lady, she’ll go crazy when she sees it’s missing.

original: Be not acknown on ’t,
modern: Don’t admit to knowing anything about it. I need it. Now go, leave me.

original: I will in Cassio’s lodging lose this napkin And let him find it. Trifles light as air Are to the jealous confirmations strong As proofs of holy writ. This may do something. Dangerous conceits are in their natures poisons Which at the first are scarce found to distaste, But with a little act upon the blood Burn like the mines of sulfur.
modern: I’ll leave this handkerchief at Cassio’s house and let him find it.To a jealous man, a meaningless little thing like this looks like absolute proof. This handkerchief may be useful to me. The Moor’s mind has already become infected with my poisonous suggestions. Ideas can be like poisons. At first they hardly even taste bad, but once they get into your blood they start burning like hot lava.

original: I did say so. Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world, Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep Which thou owedst yesterday.
modern: Here he comes. No drugs or sleeping pills will ever give you the restful sleep that you had last night.

original: Ha! Ha! False to me?
modern: Argh! She’s cheating on me?

original: Why, how now, general? No more of that.
modern: Oh, general, please, no more of that!

original: I swear ’tis better to be much abused Than but to know ’t a little.
modern: Get lost! You’ve tortured me with these thoughts. It is better to be tricked completely than to only suspect a little.

original: How now, my lord!
modern: What’s with you, my lord?

original: What sense had I in her stol'n hours of lust? I saw ’t not, thought it not, it harmed not me. I found not Cassio’s kisses on her lips. He that is robbed, not wanting what is stol'n, Let him not know’t, and he’s not robbed at all.
modern: I had no idea she was cheating on me. I never saw it or suspected it, so it never hurt me. I slept well, ate well, and was happy. I never saw Cassio’s kisses on her lips. A man who’s robbed, but doesn’t miss what’s stolen, isn’t robbed at all.

original: I am sorry to hear this.
modern: I’m sorry to hear this.

original: Pioneers and all, had tasted her sweet body, So I had nothing known. Oh, now forever Farewell the tranquil mind! Farewell content! Farewell the plumèd troops and the big wars Farewell the neighing steed and the shrill trump, The spirit-stirring drum, th' ear-piercing fife, The royal banner, and all quality, Pride, pomp, and circumstance of glorious war! The immortal Jove’s dead clamors counterfeit, Farewell! Othello’s occupation’s gone.
modern: I would’ve been happy if the whole army had had sex with her, the lowest-ranking grunts and all, as long as I didn’t know anything about it. Oh, goodbye to my peace of mind! Goodbye to my happiness! Goodbye to the soldiers and to the wars that make men great! Goodbye! Goodbye to the horses and the trumpets and the drums, the flute and the splendid banners, and all those proud displays and pageantry of war! And you deadly cannons that roar like thunderbolts thrown by the gods, goodbye! Othello’s career is over.

original: Is ’t possible, my lord?
modern: Is this possible, my lord?

original: Villain, be sure thou prove my love a whore, Or by the worth of mine eternal soul Thou hadst been better have been born a dog Than answer my waked wrath!
modern: You villain, you’d better be able to prove my wife’s a whore! Be sure of it. Get me proof I can see. If you can’t, trust me, you won’t want to feel my rage!

original: Is ’t come to this?
modern: Has it come to this?

original: Make me to see ’t, or at the least so prove it To hang a doubt on, or woe upon thy life!
modern: Show me, or at least prove it beyond the shadow of a doubt. If you can’t, your life is worthless!

original: My noble lord—
modern: My noble lord—

original: If thou dost slander her and torture me, Never pray more. Abandon all remorse. Do deeds to make heaven weep, all earth amazed, For nothing canst thou to damnation add Greater than that.
modern: If you’re slandering her just to torture me, then it’ll be no use to pray for mercy or say you’re sorry. You might as well go ahead and commit every unspeakable crime you can think of, because there’s nothing you could that would top what you’ve already done!

original: Oh, grace! Oh, heaven forgive me! Are you a man? Have you a soul or sense? That lov’st to make thine honesty a vice! O monstrous world! Take note, take note, O world, To be direct and honest is not safe. I thank you for this profit, and from hence
modern: Oh, heaven help me! Aren’t you a rational human being? Don’t you have any sense at all? Goodbye. I resign my official position. I’m such an idiot for always telling the truth! What a horrible world we live in! Listen, pay attention, everybody. It’s not safe to be straightforward and honest. I’m glad you’ve taught me this valuable lesson. From now on, I’ll never try to help a friend when it hurts him so much to hear the truth.

original: Nay, stay. Thou shouldst be honest.
modern: No, stop. You should always be honest.

original: I should be wise, for honesty’s a fool And loses that it works for.
modern: I should always be wise. Honesty’s stupid, it makes me lose my friends even when I’m trying to help them.

original: By the world, I think my wife be honest and think she is not. I’ll have some proof. Her name, that was as fresh As Dian’s visage, is now begrimed and black As mine own face. If there be cords or knives, Poison, or fire, or suffocating streams,
modern:
I swear, I think my wife’s faithful, and I think she’s not. I think you’re trustworthy one minute and then not the next. I need proof! Her reputation was as pure as the snow, but now it’s as dirty and black as my own face. As long as there are 

ropes, knives, poison, fire, or streams to drown in
By referring to instruments of death, Othello implies that he wants to commit either suicide or murder

ropes, knives, poison, fire, or streams to drown in , I won’t stand for this. Oh, how I wish I knew the truth!

original: I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion. I do repent me that I put it to you. You would be satisfied?
modern: I see you’re all eaten up with emotion. I’m sorry I said anything. You want proof?

original: Would? Nay, and I will.
modern: Want? Yes, I want it, and I’ll get it.

original: And may, but how? How satisfied, my lord? Behold her topped?
modern: But how? How will you get proof? Are you going to hide and watch them having sex?

original: Death and damnation! Oh!
modern: Death and damnation! Oh!

original: It were a tedious difficulty, I think, To bring them to that prospect. Damn them then, If ever mortal eyes do see them bolster What shall I say? Where’s satisfaction? It is impossible you should see this, Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys, As salt as wolves in pride, and fools as gross If imputation and strong circumstances Which lead directly to the door of truth Will give you satisfaction, you may have ’t.
modern: I think it would be very hard to arrange for them to have sex while you watched. If anyone sees them in bed together besides themselves, I guess we could damn them then. So what can we do? What can I say? What proof is there? It’d be impossible for you to watch them, even if they were as horny as animals in heat and as stupid as drunks. But if you would be willing to accept circumstantial evidence as proof, we can get that.

original: Give me a living reason she’s disloyal.
modern: Give me one good reason to think she’s cheating on me.

original: But, sith I am entered in this cause so far, Pricked to ’t by foolish honesty and love, I will go on. I lay with Cassio lately And, being troubled with a raging tooth, So loose of soul that in their sleeps will mutter
modern: I don’t like what you’re asking me to do. But since I’ve gotten myself involved this far, because I’m so stupidly honest and because I like you so much, I’ll keep going. I recently shared a bed with Cassio, and I couldn’t sleep because of a raging toothache. Well, some people talk in their sleep, and Cassio is one of them. I heard him saying, “Sweet Desdemona, let’s be careful and hide our love,” in his sleep. And then he grabbed my hand and said, “Oh, my darling!” and

original: Their affairs. One of this kind is Cassio. In sleep I heard him say “Sweet Desdemona, Let us be wary, let us hide our loves.” Cry “O sweet creature!” and then kiss me hard, As if he plucked up kisses by the roots That grew upon my lips, lay his leg Over my thigh, and sigh, and kiss, and then
modern: kissed me hard, as if he were trying to suck my lips off. Then he put his leg over mine, and sighed and kissed me, and said, “Damn fate for giving you to the Moor!”

original: Oh, monstrous! Monstrous!
modern: Oh, that’s monstrous! Monstrous!

original: Nay, this was but his dream.
modern: No, it was just a dream.

original: But this denoted a foregone conclusion.
modern: But it shows that something has already happened.

original: 'Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream. That do demonstrate thinly.
modern: It’s a reason for suspicion, even though it’s just a dream. And it might back up other evidence that may seem too flimsy.

original: I’ll tear her all to pieces!
modern: I’ll tear her to pieces!

original: Nay, yet be wise, yet we see nothing done, She may be honest yet. Tell me but this, Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief
modern: No, be reasonable. We don’t have any proof yet. She might still be faithful. Just tell me this: have you ever seen her holding a handkerchief with an embroidered strawberry pattern on it?

original: I gave her such a one, ’twas my first gift.
modern: Yes, I gave her one like that. It was my first gift to her.

original: I know not that, but such a handkerchief— I am sure it was your wife’s—did I today See Cassio wipe his beard with.
modern: I don’t know about that, but I saw a handkerchief like that today. I’m sure it belongs to your wife, and I saw Cassio use it to wipe his beard.

original: If it be that—
modern: If it’s the same one—

original: It speaks against her with the other proofs.
modern: If it’s the same one, or any one that belongs to her, then together with the other evidence it’s pretty strong.

original: Oh, that the slave had forty thousand lives! One is too poor, too weak for my revenge. Now do I see ’tis true. Look here, Iago, 'Tis gone. Arise, black vengeance, from the hollow hell! Yield up, O love, thy crown and hearted throne To tyrannous hate! Swell, bosom, with thy fraught,
modern: Oh, I’d kill that bastard Cassio forty thousand times if I could! Killing him once is not enough revenge. Now I see it’s true. Oh, Iago, all the love I felt is gone, vanished in the wind. Welcome, hatred and vengeance! Get out of my heart, love! My heart feels like it’s full of poisonous snakes!

original: Yet be content.
modern: Calm down—

original: Oh, blood, blood, blood!
modern: I want blood!

original: Patience, I say. Your mind may change.
modern: Be patient, I’m telling you. You may change your mind later.

original: Never, Iago. Like to the Pontic sea, Whose icy current and compulsive course Ne'er keeps retiring ebb but keeps due on Even so my bloody thoughts with violent pace Shall ne'er look back, ne'er ebb to humble love Till that a capable and wide revenge Swallow them up. Now, by yon marble heaven, I here engage my words. (he kneels)
modern: Never, Iago. My thoughts of revenge are flowing through me like a violent river, never turning back to love, only flowing toward full revenge that’ll swallow them up. I swear to God I’ll get revenge. (he kneels)

original: Do not rise yet. Witness, you ever-burning lights above, You elements that clip us round about, Witness that here Iago doth give up To wronged Othello’s service. Let him command, And to obey shall be in me remorse, What bloody business ever.
modern: Don’t get up yet. Let heaven be my witness—I’m putting my mind, my heart, and my hands in Othello’s control. Let him command me, and I’ll do whatever he asks, no matter how violent.

original: I greet thy love Not with vain thanks but with acceptance bounteous, Within these three days let me hear thee say That Cassio’s not alive.
modern: I accept your devotion with my deepest love. I’ll put you to the test right away. Within the next three days I want to hear you tell me that Cassio’s dead.

original: My friend is dead, 'Tis done at your request. But let her live.
modern: My friend Cassio is dead. It’s done, because you request it. But let her live.

original: Damn her, lewd minx! Oh, damn her, damn her! To furnish me with some swift means of death For the fair devil. Now art thou my lieutenant.
modern: Damn her, the wicked whore! Oh, damn her, damn her! Come away with me. I’m going inside to think up some way to kill that beautiful devil. You’re my lieutenant now.

original: I am your own for ever.
modern: I’m yours forever.

original: Do you know, sirrah, where Lieutenant Cassio lies?
modern:
Excuse me, do you know which room Lieutenant Cassio  lies in
lies in = sleeps inlies in?

original: I dare not say he lies anywhere.
modern: I wouldn’t dare say he lies anywhere.

original: Why, man?
modern: Why do you say that?

original: He’s a soldier, and for one to say a soldier lies, ’tis stabbing.
modern: He’s a soldier. If I accused a soldier of lying, he’d stab me.

original: To tell you where he lodges is to tell you where I lie.
modern: Telling you where he’s sleeping is like telling you where I’m lying.

original: Can anything be made of this?
modern: What on earth does that mean?

original: I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise a lodging and say he lies here, or he lies there, were to lie in mine own throat.
modern: I don’t know where he’s staying, so if I told you he’s sleeping here or there, I’d be lying.

original: Can you inquire him out and be edified by report?
modern: Can you ask around and find out?

original: Seek him, bid him come hither. Tell him I have moved my lord on his behalf, and hope all will be well.
modern: Find him and tell him to come here. Tell him I’ve spoken to my husband on his behalf, and I think everything will be all right.

original: To do this is within the compass of man’s wit, and therefore I will attempt the doing it.
modern: I think I can do that. It’s not too much to ask.

original: Where should I lose that handkerchief, Emilia?
modern: Where could I have lost that handkerchief, Emilia?

original: I know not, madam.
modern: I don’t know, madam.

original: Full of crusadoes. And but my noble Moor Is true of mind and made of no such baseness As jealous creatures are, it were enough To put him to ill thinking.
modern: Believe me, I’d rather have lost a purse full of gold coins. This would be enough to make my husband suspect me, if he wasn’t so free of jealousy.

original: Who, he? I think the sun where he was born Drew all such humors from him.
modern: Who, him? I think all tendencies to jealousy were burned out of him by the sun of his native land.

original: Look where he comes.
modern: Look, here he comes.

original: I will not leave him now till Cassio
modern: I won’t leave him alone until he gives Cassio his job back.—How are you, my lord?

original: Well, my good lady.—(aside) Oh, hardness to dissemble!— How do you, Desdemona?
modern: I’m fine, my lady.—(to himself) Oh, it’s so hard to pretend!—How are you, Desdemona?

original: Well, my good lord.
modern: I’m fine, my lord.

original: Give me your hand. This hand is moist, my lady.
modern:
Give me your  hand
Moist hands were supposed to indicate a tendency toward love.hand. Your hand’s moist, my lady.

original: It hath felt no age nor known no sorrow.
modern: It’s moist because it’s still young and inexperienced.

original: Hot, hot, and moist. This hand of yours requires A sequester from liberty, fasting, and prayer,
modern: It says you’re fertile, and you’ve got a giving heart. Hot, hot and moist. With a hand like this you need to

original: Much castigation, exercise devout, For here’s a young and sweating devil here, A frank one.
modern: fast and pray to stave off temptations. Someone with a young sweating hand like this one is bound to act up sooner or later. It’s a nice hand, an open one.

original: You may indeed say so, For ’twas that hand that gave away my heart.
modern: You’re right to say that. This was the hand that gave you my heart.

original: A liberal hand. The hearts of old gave hands, But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.
modern: This hand gives itself away very freely. In the old days, people used to give their hearts to each other when they joined their hands in marriage. But these days, people give each other their hands without their hearts.

original: What promise, chuck?
modern: What did I promise, my dear?

original: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.
modern: I sent for Cassio to come talk with you.

original: I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me. Lend me thy handkerchief.
modern: I have a bad cold that’s bothering me. Lend me your handkerchief.

original: Here, my lord.
modern: Here, my lord.

original: I have it not about me.
modern: I don’t have it with me.

original: Not?
modern: You don’t?

original: No, indeed, my lord.
modern: No, my lord.

original: That’s a fault. That handkerchief Did an Egyptian to my mother give, She was a charmer and could almost read
modern: That’s not good. An Egyptian woman gave that handkerchief to my mother. She was a witch, and she could

original: The thoughts of people. She told her, while she kept it Entirely to her love, but if she lost it Or made gift of it, my father’s eye Should hold her loathèd and his spirits should hunt After new fancies. She, dying, gave it me To give it her. I did so, and take heed on ’t, Make it a darling like your precious eye. To lose ’t or give ’t away were such perdition As nothing else could match.
modern: almost read people’s thoughts. She told my mother that as long as she kept it with her, my father would love and desire her. But if she lost it or gave it away, my father would start hating her and looking at other women. When she was dying she gave it to me and told me to give it to my wife when I got married. I did. So pay attention. Treat it as something precious. Losing it or giving it away would be an unspeakable loss, a loss like none other.

original: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is that possible?

original: A sibyl, that had numbered in the world The sun to course two hundred compasses, In her prophetic fury sewed the work. The worms were hallowed that did breed the silk, Conserved of maidens' hearts.
modern: Yes, it’s true. There’s magic in its fabric. A two-hundred-year-old witch sewed it while she was in a fevered trance. The silk came from sacred silkworms, and it was dyed with fluid made from embalmed virgins' hearts.

original: Indeed? Is ’t true?
modern: Really? Is that true?

original: Most veritable, therefore look to ’t well.
modern: It’s absolutely true, so take good care of it.

original: Then would to Heaven that I had never seen ’t!
modern: I wish I had never seen it!

original: Ha! Wherefore?
modern: Ha! Why?

original: Is ’t lost? Is ’t gone? Speak, is ’t out o' th' way?
modern: Is it lost? Is it gone? Tell me, is it missing?

original: Bless us!
modern: God help me!

original: Say you?
modern: What do you have to say for yourself?

original: It is not lost, but what and if it were?
modern: It’s not lost, but what if it were?

original: I say, it is not lost.
modern: I’m telling you, it’s not lost.

original: Fetch ’t, let me see ’t.
modern: Then bring it here. Let me see it.

original: Why, so I can, sir, but I will not now. This is a trick to put me from my suit. Pray you, let Cassio be received again.
modern: I could, sir. But I don’t want to now. This is just a trick to take my mind off what I’m asking you for. Please hire Cassio again.

original: Come, come, You’ll never meet a more sufficient man.
modern: Come on. You know you’ll never find a more capable man.

original: The handkerchief!
modern: The handkerchief!

original: A man that all his time Hath founded his good fortunes on your love,
modern: He’s counted on your friendship for his success. He’s shared dangers with you—

original: The handkerchief!
modern: The handkerchief!

original: In sooth, you are to blame.
modern: Really, I don’t think you’re behaving very well.

original: Away!
modern: Damn it!

original: Is not this man jealous?
