modern: And you say he’s not jealous?

original: I ne'er saw this before. I am most unhappy in the loss of it.
modern: I never saw him like this before. There must be some magic in that handkerchief. I’m miserable that I lost it.

original: 'Tis not a year or two shows us a man. They are all but stomachs, and we all but food. To eat us hungerly, and when they are full,
modern: Men are all the same, but it takes longer than a year or two to see how bad they are. They’re like stomachs and we’re just the food. They eat us up hungrily, and when they’re full, they vomit us up. Look, here comes Cassio and my husband.

original: There is no other way. 'Tis she must do ’t, And, lo, the happiness! Go and importune her.
modern: There’s no other way. She’s the one who’s got to do it. And what luck, she’s here! Go ahead and ask her.

original: How now, good Cassio, what’s the news with you?
modern: Hello, Cassio. How are you?

original: Madam, my former suit. I do beseech you Exist, and be a member of his love Whom I, with all the office of my heart Entirely honor. I would not be delayed. If my offence be of such mortal kind Nor purposed merit in futurity, Can ransom me into his love again, But to know so must be my benefit. So shall I clothe me in a forced content, To fortune’s alms.
modern: Nothing, madam. Just my earlier request. I’m begging you to help me get back on his good side. I’m devoted to him with all my heart. I can’t wait any longer. If my wrongdoing was so serious that I can’t get back into his good graces either by my past service, or my present situation, or the promise of devoted service in the future, just knowing that would help me. Then I could stop wondering, and find some other career.

original: Alas, thrice-gentle Cassio, My advocation is not now in tune. My lord is not my lord, nor should I know him Were he in favor as in humor altered. As I have spoken for you all my best And stood within the blank of his displeasure For my free speech. You must awhile be patient. What I can do I will, and more I will
modern: I’m sorry, dear Cassio, but now is not the right time to bring up your case. My husband’s not himself. If his face changed as much as his personality has, I wouldn’t recognize him. God knows I have done my best to argue for you, and made him angry at me for being so aggressive. You’ll just have to be patient for a little while. I’ll do what I can, more than I’d do for myself. Let that be enough for you.

original: Is my lord angry?
modern: Is Othello angry?

original: He went hence but now, And certainly in strange unquietness.
modern: He just left, clearly upset about something.

original: Can he be angry? I have seen the cannon When it hath blown his ranks into the air Puffed his own brother—and is he angry? Something of moment then, I will go meet him. There’s matter in ’t indeed, if he be angry.
modern: Can he even get angry? It’s hard to believe. I’ve seen him stay calm when cannons were blowing his soldiers to bits, even killing his own brother without him batting an eyelid—is he really upset? It must be about something important. I’ll go talk to him. If he’s angry, there must be something seriously wrong.

original: I prithee, do so.
modern: Please, do so.

original: Something, sure, of state, Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him, Hath puddled his clear spirit, and in such cases Men’s natures wrangle with inferior things, Though great ones are their object. 'Tis even so, Our other healthful members even to that sense Of pain. Nay, we must think men are not gods, Nor of them look for such observances As fit the bridal. Beshrew me much, Emilia, Arraigning his unkindness with my soul, But now I find I had suborned the witness, And he’s indicted falsely.
modern: There must be some political news from Venice, or some dangerous plot here in Cyprus has ruined his good mood. Men always get angry about little things when they’re really worried about bigger ones. That’s the way it goes. When our finger hurts, it makes the rest of the body hurt too. We shouldn’t expect men to be perfect, or for them to be as polite as on the weddingday. Oh, Emilia, I’m so inexperienced that I thought he was being unkind, but actually I was judging him harshly.

original: Pray heaven it be State matters, as you think, and no conception
modern: I hope to God it’s something political, like you think, and not jealousy involving you.

original: Alas the day! I never gave him cause.
modern: Oh no! I never gave him reason to be jealous.

original: But jealous souls will not be answered so. They are not ever jealous for the cause, But jealous for they’re jealous. It is a monster
modern: But jealous people don’t think like that. They’re never jealous for a reason; they’re just jealous. It’s like a monster that just grows and grows, out of nothing.

original: Heaven keep the monster from Othello’s mind!
modern: I hope God keeps that monster from growing in Othello’s mind!

original: Lady, amen.
modern: Amen to that, lady.

original: I will go seek him.—Cassio, walk hereabout. If I do find him fit, I’ll move your suit
modern: I’ll go look for him—Cassio, stay around here. If he’s in a good mood I’ll mention you again, and do everything I can.

original: I humbly thank your ladyship.
modern: I thank you, lady.

original: Save you, friend Cassio!
modern: Hello, Cassio!

original: What make you from home? How is ’t with you, my most fair Bianca? Indeed, sweet love, I was coming to your house.
modern: Why are you so far from home? How are you, my pretty Bianca? To tell you the truth, I was just going to your house.

original: What, keep a week away? Seven days and nights? Eight score eight hours? And lovers' absent hours More tedious than the dial eightscore times! Oh weary reckoning!
modern: And I was just going to yours. You’ve kept away from me for a week? Seven days and seven nights? A hundred and sixty-eight hours? And lovers' hours are a hundred and sixty times longer than normal ones! What a tedious wait!

original: Pardon me, Bianca, But I shall, in a more continuate time, Strike off this score of absence. Sweet Bianca, (giving her DESDEMONA’s handkerchief) Take me this work out.
modern: I’m sorry, Bianca. All this time I’ve been depressed and had problems on my mind. When I get some free time I’ll make it up to you. (he gives her DESDEMONA ’s handkerchief) Sweet Bianca, would you copy this embroidery pattern for me?

original: O Cassio, whence came this? To the felt absence now I feel a cause. Is ’t come to this? Well, well.
modern: Oh, Cassio, where did you get this? This is a gift from another woman, a new lover! Now I know why you’ve been staying away from me. Has it come to this? Well, well.

original: Go to, woman, Throw your vile guesses in the devil’s teeth From whence you have them. You are jealous now No, in good troth, Bianca.
modern: Oh, come on, woman. Stop jumping to silly conclusions. Now you’re jealous, thinking that this is from some mistress of mine, but I swear it’s not, Bianca.

original: Why, whose is it?
modern: Well, whose is it?

original: I know not neither, I found it in my chamber. I like the work well. Ere it be demanded, As like enough it will, I would have it copied.
modern: I don’t even know. I found it in my room. It’s pretty. Someone is certainly looking for it, and I’ll have to give it back. So I’d like it copied. Take it and do that for me, and leave me alone for a while.

original: Leave you! Wherefore?
modern: Leave you alone! Why?

original: I do attend here on the general And think it no addition, nor my wish, To have him see me womaned.
modern: I’m waiting here for the general, and I don’t want him to see me with a woman.

original: Why, I pray you?
modern: And why’s that?

original: But that you do not love me. I pray you bring me on the way a little And say if I shall see you soon at night.
modern: But you don’t love me. Please, just walk with me a little ways, and tell me if I’ll see you later tonight.

original: 'Tis but a little way that I can bring you, For I attend here. But I’ll see you soon.
modern: I can only walk a little way with you, since I’m waiting here. But I’ll see you soon.

original: Will you think so?
modern: Do you really think so?

original: Think so, Iago?
modern: What do you mean, do I think so?

original: What, To kiss in private?
modern: What, just because they kissed in private?

original: An unauthorized kiss!
modern: An illicit kiss!

original: Or to be naked with her friend in bed An hour or more, not meaning any harm?
modern: Maybe she was just naked in bed with him for an hour or so, but they didn’t do anything.

original: It is hypocrisy against the devil. They that mean virtuously, and yet do so, The devil their virtue tempts, and they tempt heaven.
modern: Naked in bed together, but without doing anything? Come on, Iago. That would be like playing a trick on the devil: they’d make him think they’re going to commit adultery, but then back off. Anyone who acted like that would be letting the devil tempt them, and tempting God to condemn them.

original: So they do nothing, ’tis a venial slip.
modern: As long as they didn’t do anything, it would only be a minor sin. But if I gave my wife a handkerchief—

original: What then?
modern: Then what?

original: Why then ’tis hers, my lord, and, being hers, She may, I think, bestow ’t on any man.
modern: Then it’s hers. And if it’s hers, I guess she can give it to any man she wants.

original: She is protectress of her honor too.
modern: Her reputation is also her own. Can she give that away too?

original: Her honor is an essence that’s not seen, They have it very oft that have it not. But for the handkerchief—
modern: You can’t see a reputation. A lot of people don’t even deserve the reputations they have. But a handkerchief—

original: By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it. As doth the raven o'er the infectious house, Boding to all—he had my handkerchief.
modern: God, I wish I could forget about the handkerchief! What you told me it haunts me like a nightmare—he’s got my handkerchief!

original: Ay, what of that?
modern: Yes, what about it?

original: That’s not so good now.
modern: That’s not good.

original: What if I had said I had seen him do you wrong? Who having, by their own importunate suit, Or voluntary dotage of some mistress, Convincèd or supplied them, cannot choose But they must blab—
modern: What if I’d said I saw him do something to hurt you? Or heard him say something about it. You know there are jerks out there who have to brag about bedding some woman.—

original: Hath he said any thing?
modern: Has he said anything?

original: No more than he’ll unswear.
modern: Yes, but he’d deny it all.

original: What hath he said?
modern: What did he say?

original: Why, that he did—I know not what he did.
modern: He said he did—I don’t know.

original: What? what?
modern: He what?

original: Lie—
modern: He was in bed with—

original: With her?
modern: With her?

original: With her, on her, what you will.
modern: With her, on top of her—however you want to say it.

original: Lie with her? lie on her? We say “lie on her” when they belie her! Lie with her—that’s fulsome. Handkerchief—confessions—handkerchief! To confess, and be hanged for his labor. First to be hanged, and then to confess—I tremble at it. Nature would not invest herself in such shadowing passion without some instruction. It is not words that shake me thus. Pish! Noses, ears, and lips. Is ’t possible? Confess!—Handkerchief!—Oh, devil!—
modern: In bed with her? On top of her? I would have thought people were telling lies about her rather than believe he was lying on her. My God, it’s nauseating! Handkerchief—confessions—handkerchief! I’ll kill him first, and then let him confess—I’m trembling with rage. I wouldn’t be trembling like this if I didn’t know deep down this was all true. Noses, ears, lips. Is it possible? Tell me the truth—Handkerchief—Damn it!

original: And many worthy and chaste dames even thus, All guiltless, meet reproach.—What, ho! My lord! My lord, I say! Othello!
modern: Keep working, poison! This is the way to trick gullible fools. Many good and innocent women are punished for reasons like this.—My lord? My lord, Othello!

original: How now, Cassio!
modern: Hey, Cassio!

original: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

original: This is his second fit. He had one yesterday.
modern: Othello’s having some kind of epileptic fit. This is his second fit like this. He had one yesterday.

original: Rub him about the temples.
modern: Rub his temples.

original: No, forbear. The lethargy must have his quiet course. If not, he foams at mouth and by and by Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
modern: No, don’t. This fit has to run its course. If you interrupt it, he’ll foam at the mouth and go crazy. Look, he’s moving. Why don’t you go away for a bit? He’ll get

original: He will recover straight. When he is gone I would on great occasion speak with you.
modern: better right away. When he leaves, it’s very important that I talk to you.

original: How is it, general? Have you not hurt your head?
modern: What happened, general? Did you hit your head?

original: I mock you not, by heaven. Would you would bear your fortune like a man!
modern: Making fun of you? No, I swear! I wish you could face your bad news like a man!

original: A hornèd man’s a monster and a beast.
modern: A man who’s been cheated on isn’t a real man. He’s subhuman, like an animal.

original: There’s many a beast then in a populous city, And many a civil monster.
modern: In that case there are a lot of animals on the loose in this city.

original: Good sir, be a man, Think every bearded fellow that’s but yoked May draw with you. There’s millions now alive That nightly lie in those unproper beds Which they dare swear peculiar. Your case is better. To lip a wanton in a secure couch, And to suppose her chaste. No, let me know, And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.
modern: Sir, be a man. Every married man has been cheated on. Millions of men sleep with wives who cheat on them, wrongly believing they belong to them alone. Your case is better than that. At least you’re not ignorant. The worst thing of all is to kiss your wife thinking she’s innocent, when in fact she’s a whore. No, I’d rather know the truth. Then I’ll know exactly what she is, just as I know what I am.

original: Oh, thou art wise! 'Tis certain.
modern: You’re wise! That’s for sure.

original: Stand you awhile apart, Whilst you were here o'erwhelmèd with your grief— A passion most resulting such a man— Cassio came hither. I shifted him away And laid good ’scuses upon your ecstasy,
modern: Go somewhere else for a while. Calm down. While you were dazed by grief—which isn’t appropriate for a man like you—Cassio showed up here. I got him to leave, and made up an excuse for your trance. I told him to come back and talk to me in a bit, and he promised he would. So hide here and watch how he sneers

original: The which he promised. Do but encave yourself, And mark the fleers, the gibes, and notable scorns That dwell in every region of his face. For I will make him tell the tale anew He hath, and is again to cope your wife. I say, but mark his gesture. Marry, patience, Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen, And nothing of a man.
modern: at you. I’ll make him tell me the whole story again—where, how often, how long ago—and when he plans to sleep with your wife in the future. I’m telling you, just watch his face. But stay calm, and don’t get carried away by rage, or I’ll think you’re not a man.

original: Dost thou hear, Iago? But—dost thou hear?—most bloody.
modern: Do you hear what I’m saying, Iago? I’ll be very patient, but—do you hear me?—I’m not done with him yet

original: That’s not amiss, But yet keep time in all. Will you withdraw?
modern: That’s fine, but for now keep your cool. Will you go hide?

original: Now will I question Cassio of Bianca, A huswife that by selling her desires That dotes on Cassio, as ’tis the strumpet’s plague To beguile many and be beguiled by one. He, when he hears of her, cannot refrain From the excess of laughter. Here he comes.
modern: Now I’ll ask Cassio about Bianca, a prostitute who sells her body for food and clothes. She’s crazy about Cassio. That’s the whore’s curse, to seduce many men, but to be seduced by one. Whenever he talks about her he can’t stop laughing.

original: And his unbookish jealousy must construe Poor Cassio’s smiles, gestures, and light behavior Quite in the wrong.—How do you now, lieutenant?
modern: And when he laughs, Othello will go crazy. In his ignorant jealousy, he’ll totally misunderstand Cassio’s smiles, gestures, and jokes.—How are you, lieutenant?

original: The worser that you give me the addition
modern: It doesn’t make me feel any better when you call me lieutenant. I’m dying to have that title back again.

original: Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure on ’t. Now if this suit lay in Bianca’s power How quickly should you speed!
modern: Just keep asking Desdemona, and it’ll be yours. If it was up to Bianca to get you your job back, you’d have had it already!

original: Alas, poor caitiff!
modern: The poor thing!

original: Look how he laughs already!
modern: He’s laughing already!

original: Alas, poor rogue, I think indeed she loves me.
modern: The poor thing, I really think she loves me.

original: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.
modern: Now he denies it a bit, and tries to laugh it off.

original: Do you hear, Cassio?
modern: Have you heard this, Cassio?

original: Now he importunes him To tell it o'er. Go to, well said, well said.
modern: He’s asking him to tell the story again. Go on, tell it.

original: Do you intend it?
modern: She says you’re going to marry her. Are you?

original: Ha, ha, ha!
modern: Ha, ha, ha!

original: Do ye triumph, Roman? Do you triumph?
modern: Are you laughing because you’ve won? Do you think you’ve won?

original: I marry her! What? A customer? Prithee bear some charity to my wit. Do not think it so unwholesome. Ha, ha, ha!
modern: Me, marry her? That whore? Please give me a little credit! I’m not that stupid. Ha, ha, ha!

original: Why the cry goes that you shall marry her.
modern: I swear, there’s a rumor going around that you’ll marry her.

original: Prithee say true!
modern: You’re kidding!

original: I am a very villain else.
modern: If it’s not true, you can call me a villain.

original: Have you scored me? Well.
modern: Have you given me bastard children to raise? All right, then.

original: Iago beckons me. Now he begins the story.
modern: Iago is gesturing for me to come closer. Now he’s telling the story.

original: She was here even now. She haunts me in every place. I was the other day talking on the sea-bank with certain Venetians, and thither comes the bauble and, by this hand, she falls me thus about my neck—
modern: She was here just now. She hangs around me all the time. I was talking to some Venetians down by the shore, and the fool showed up. I swear to you, she put her arms around me like this—

original: Crying “O dear Cassio!” as it were. His gesture imports it.
modern: Saying, “Oh, Cassio,” it seems, judging by his gestures.

original: So hangs and lolls and weeps upon me, so shakes, and pulls me! Ha, ha, ha!
modern: She hangs around me and dangles from my neck and cries, shaking me and pulling at me. Ha, ha, ha!

original: Well, I must leave her company.
modern: I have to get rid of her.

original: Before me! Look, where she comes.
modern: Look out, here she comes.

original: 'Tis such another fitchew. Marry, a perfumed one.— What do you mean by this haunting of me?
modern: It’s a whore like all the others, stinking of cheap perfume.—Why are you always hanging around me?

original: How now, my sweet Bianca! How now, how now?
modern: What is it, my dear Bianca? What’s wrong?

original: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!
modern: My God, that’s my handkerchief!

original: If you’ll come to supper tonight, you may. If you will not, come when you are next prepared for.
modern: If you want to come have dinner with me, you can. If you don’t want to, then good riddance.

original: After her, after her.
modern: Go after her, go.

original: Will you sup there?
modern: Will you be having dinner with her tonight?

original: Yes, I intend so.
modern: Yes, I will.

original: Well, I may chance to see you, for I would very fain speak with you.
modern: Well, maybe I’ll see you there. I’d really like to speak with you.

original: Prithee come, will you?
modern: Please come. Will you?

original: (advancing) How shall I murder him, Iago?
modern: (coming forward) How should I murder him, Iago?

original: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?
modern: Did you see how he laughed about sleeping with her?

original: O Iago!
modern: Oh Iago!

original: And did you see the handkerchief?
modern: And did you see the handkerchief?

original: Yours by this hand. And to see how he prizes the foolish woman your wife! She gave it him, and he hath given it his whore.
modern: It was yours, I swear. And do you see how much your foolish wife means to him? She gave it to him, and he gave it to his whore.

original: I would have him nine years a-killing. A fine woman! A fair woman! A sweet woman!
modern: I wish I could keep killing him for nine years straight. Oh, she’s a fine woman! A fair woman! A sweet woman!

original: Nay, you must forget that.
modern: No, you have to forget all that now.

original: Ay, let her rot and perish and be damned tonight, for she shall not live. No, my heart is turned to stone. I strike it and it hurts my hand. Oh, the world hath not a sweeter creature, she might lie by an emperor’s side and command him tasks.
modern: Yes, let her die and rot and go to hell tonight. She won’t stay alive for long. No, my heart’s turned to stone—when I hit it, it hurts my hand. Oh, the world never saw a sweeter creature. She could be married to an emperor, and he’d be like her slave!

original: Hang her! I do but say what she is. So delicate with her needle, an admirable musician. Oh, she will sing the savageness out of a bear! Of so high and plenteous wit and invention!
modern: Damn her, I’m just describing her truthfully! She’s so good at sewing, and a wonderful musician. Oh, she could sing a wild bear to sleep! Oh, she’s so witty and creative!

original: She’s the worse for all this.
modern: All the worse that she stooped this low, then.

original: Oh, a thousand thousand times—and then of so gentle a condition!
modern: Oh, a thousand times worse, a thousand times—and what a sweet personality she has!

original: Ay, too gentle.
modern: Yes, a little too sweet.

original: If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her patent to offend, for if it touch not you it comes near nobody.
modern: If you still feel so affectionate toward her, then why not give her permission to cheat on you? If it doesn’t bother you, it won’t bother anyone else.

original: I will chop her into messes! Cuckold me?
modern: I’ll chop her into pieces. How could she cheat on me?

original: Oh, ’tis foul in her.
modern: Oh, it’s horrible of her.

original: With mine officer!
modern: And with my own officer!

original: Get me some poison, Iago, this night. I’ll not expostulate with her, lest her body and beauty unprovide my mind again—This night, Iago!
modern: Get me some poison tonight, Iago. I won’t argue with her, so her beautiful body won’t disarm me.—Tonight, Iago.

original: Do it not with poison. Strangle her in her bed, even the bed she hath contaminated.
modern: Don’t do it with poison. Strangle her in her bed, the same bed she’s contaminated.

original: Good, good, the justice of it pleases! Very good!
modern: Good, good, I like that—it’s only fair! Very good!

original: And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker. You shall hear more by midnight.
modern: And let me kill Cassio. You’ll hear more from me by midnight.

original: What trumpet is that same?
modern: What’s that trumpet for?

original: I warrant something from Venice. 'Tis Lodovico, this, comes from the duke. See, your wife’s with him.
modern: I think someone’s coming from Venice. It’s Lodovico. He must be coming from the duke. Look, your wife is with him.

original: Save you, worthy general!
modern: Greetings, good general!

original: With all my heart, sir.
modern: Greetings, sir.

original: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.
modern: The duke and senators of Venice greet you.

original: And what’s the news, good cousin Lodovico?
modern: What’s new, cousin Lodovico?

original: I am very glad to see you, signior. Welcome to Cyprus.
modern: Very nice to see you, sir. Welcome to Cyprus.

original: I thank you. How does lieutenant Cassio?
modern: Thank you. How is lieutenant Cassio?

original: Lives, sir.
modern: Well, he’s alive.

original: An unkind breach, but you shall make all well.
modern: Cousin, there’s been a falling out between him and Othello. An unfortunate rift, but you can fix it.

original: Are you sure of that?
modern: Are you sure of that?

original: My lord?
modern: Excuse me?

original: (reads) “This fail you not to do, as you will—”
modern: (reading) “Don’t fail to do this, since you’ll—”

original: Is there division ’twixt my lord and Cassio?
modern: He didn’t say anything, he’s reading. So there’s a rift between Othello and Cassio?

original: A most unhappy one. I would do much T' atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio.
modern: Yes, unfortunately. I’d do anything to bring them back together, since I really care for Cassio.

original: Fire and brimstone!
modern: Damn it all!

original: My lord?
modern: Excuse me, my lord?

original: Are you wise?
modern: Are you in your right mind?

original: Maybe the letter moved him, For, as I think, they do command him home, Deputing Cassio in his government.
modern: Maybe the letter upset him. I think they want him to go home and appoint Cassio governor in his place.

original: Trust me, I am glad on ’t.
modern: I’m happy about that.

original: Indeed!
modern: Oh, are you really!

original: I am glad to see you mad.
modern: I’m glad you’re insane enough to admit it in front of me.

original: Why, sweet Othello—
modern: Why, sweet Othello—

original: (striking her) Devil!
modern: (striking her) You devil!

original: I have not deserved this.
modern: I haven’t done anything to deserve this!

original: Though I should swear I saw ’t. 'Tis very much. Make her amends, she weeps.
modern: My lord, no one will believe this in Venice, even though I’d swear I saw it with my own eyes. That was too much. You should apologize. She’s crying.

original: Oh, devil, devil! If that the earth could teem with woman’s tears, Each drop she falls would prove a crocodile.
modern: Oh, you devil, you devil! You can cry all day and all night, and I still won’t believe you’re sad. Get out of my sight!

original: I will not stay to offend you.
modern: I wouldn’t want to stay here and make you angry.

original: Truly, an obedient lady. I do beseech your lordship, call her back.
modern: She’s obedient—a fine lady. Please, my lord, call her back.

original: Mistress!
modern: Madam!

original: What would you with her, sir?
modern: What do you want with her, sir?

original: Who, I, my lord?
modern: Who, me?

original: Ay, you did wish that I would make her turn. Sir, she can turn, and turn, and yet go on, And she’s obedient, as you say, obedient, Very obedient.—Proceed you in your tears.— Concerning this, sir—Oh, well-painted passion!— I am commanded home.—Get you away, And will return to Venice.—Hence, avaunt!
modern: Yes, you asked me to call her back. See how well she can turn? She can turn and turn, and then turn on you again. And she can cry, sir—oh, how she can cry! And she’s obedient, as you say, obedient. Very obedient—keep crying.—Concerning this—oh, what fake emotion!—I am being ordered home—Get away from me, I’ll send for you later.—Sir, I’ll obey the order and return to Venice. Get away from me, you witch!

original: Cassio shall have my place. And, sir, tonight I do entreat that we may sup together. You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus. Goats and monkeys!
modern: Cassio can have my job. And tonight, sir, I invite you have dinner with me. Welcome to Cyprus. Horny animals!

original: Call all in all sufficient? Is this the nature Whom passion could not shake? Whose solid virtue The shot of accident nor dart of chance Could neither graze nor pierce?
modern: Is this the same Moor whom the senate considers so capable? Is this the guy who’s supposed to never get emotional, and who never gets rattled, no matter what disaster happens?

original: He is much changed.
modern: He’s changed a great deal.

original: He’s that he is. I may not breathe my censure What he might be. If what he might he is not, I would to heaven he were!
modern: He is what he is. I won’t say anything negative about what he might be. If he isn’t what he might be, then I wish to God he were!

original: What? Strike his wife?
modern: Hitting his wife?

original: 'Faith, that was not so well. Yet would I knew
modern: It’s true, that wasn’t such a nice thing to do. But I wish I could say that’s the last time he’ll do it!

original: Is it his use? Or did the letters work upon his blood And new-create his fault?
modern: Is it a habit of his? Or did the letter make him emotional somehow, and this is the first time he’s done it?

original: Alas, alas! It is not honesty in me to speak What I have seen and known. You shall observe him, That I may save my speech. Do but go after And mark how he continues.
modern: Oh, it’s too bad! It wouldn’t be right for me to tell you everything I’ve seen and heard. You’ll see what he’s like. His own actions will show you what kind of person he is, so I won’t have to bother telling you. Just go after him and watch what he does next.

original: I am sorry that I am deceived in him.
modern: I’m sorry I was so wrong about him.

original: You have seen nothing then?
modern: You haven’t seen anything, then?

original: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.
modern: No, and I didn’t hear anything either, or suspect anything at all.

original: Yes, you have seen Cassio and she together.
modern: But you’ve seen her and Cassio together.

original: But then I saw no harm, and then I heard
modern: Yes, but I didn’t see anything wrong, and I heard every syllable they said.

original: What, did they never whisper?
modern: Didn’t they ever whisper?

original: Never, my lord.
modern: Never, my lord.

original: Nor send you out o' th' way?
modern: Or ask you to leave the room?

original: Never.
modern: Never.

original: Never, my lord.
modern: No, my lord.

original: That’s strange.
modern: That’s strange.

original: I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest, Lay down my soul at stake. If you think other If any wretch have put this in your head Let heaven requite it with the serpent’s curse For if she be not honest, chaste, and true There’s no man happy. The purest of their wives
modern: I’d swear to you on my soul that she’s a good, honest person, sir. If you suspect otherwise, stop thinking that right now because you’re wrong. If any jerk has tried to convince you she’s bad, I hope God curses him. If she’s not honest, faithful, and true, then there’s no such thing as a faithful wife or a happy husband.

original: Bid her come hither. Go.
modern: Tell her to come here. Go.

original: She says enough, yet she’s a simple bawd That cannot say as much. This is a subtle whore, A closet, lock and key, of villainous secrets. And yet she’ll kneel and pray, I have seen her do ’t.
modern: She says all the right things, but the dumbest brothel-keeper would tell the same story. Desdemona’s a tricky whore with a closet full of awful secrets, but still she’ll kneel and pray like an honest woman. I’ve seen her do it.

original: Pray, chuck, come hither.
modern: Please, dear, come here.

original: What is your pleasure?
modern: What can I do for you?

original: Let me see your eyes. Look in my face.
modern: Let me see your eyes. Look at my face.

original: What horrible fancy’s this?
modern: What horrible thing are you imagining?

original: (to EMILIA) Some of your function, mistress, Cough or cry “hem” if any body come. Your mystery, your mystery! Nay, dispatch!
modern:
(to EMILIA) Go do what you do best, madam. Leave us alone for our hanky-panky, and shut the door behind you. If somebody comes, give a shout. That’s your 

job
Othello implies that Emilia’s job is to help men and women have illicit sex.

job, your job. Go on, hurry!

original: Upon my knee, what doth your speech import? I understand a fury in your words,
modern: I’m begging you on my knees to tell me what your words mean. I can tell you’re furious, but I don’t understand what you’re saying.

original: Why, what art thou?
modern: Why? Who are you?

original: Your wife, my lord. Your true and loyal wife.
modern: I’m your wife, your true and loyal wife.

original: Come, swear it, damn thyself. Lest, being like one of heaven, the devils themselves Should fear to seize thee. Therefore be double damned,
modern: Go ahead, swear to that, so you’ll be damned to hell for lying. Otherwise the devils will mistake you for an angel and be too scared to grab you. Go ahead, make sure you damn yourself by swearing you’ve been faithful to me.

original: Heaven doth truly know it.
modern: Heaven knows I am.

original: Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.
modern: Heaven knows you’re as unfaithful as hell.

original: To whom, my lord? With whom? How am I false?
modern: Unfaithful, my lord? With whom? How am I unfaithful?

original: Ah, Desdemona, away, away, away!
modern: Leave me alone, Desdemona, go away!

original: Alas the heavy day, why do you weep? If haply you my father do suspect An instrument of this your calling back, Lay not your blame on me. If you have lost him, Why, I have lost him too.
modern: Oh, what a horrible day! Why are you crying? Because of me? If you’ve been ordered back to Venice because of my father, don’t blame me. You may have lost his respect, but so have I.

original: Had it pleased heaven All kinds of sores and shames on my bare head, Steeped me in poverty to the very lips, Given to captivity me and my utmost hopes, I should have found in some place of my soul
modern: If God had decided to treat me like Job, making me sick and covered with sores, reducing me to abject poverty, selling me into slavery and destroying all my hopes, I would have found some way to accept it with patience. But instead He’s made me a laughingstock for everyone in our time to point at and scorn! Even that I could put up with. But instead, my wife, who’s supposed to

original: The fixèd figure for the time of scorn To point his slow and moving finger at! Yet could I bear that too, well, very well. But there where I have garnered up my heart, The fountain from the which my current runs Or else dries up—to be discarded thence! Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads To knot and gender in! Turn thy complexion there, Ay, there, look grim as hell!
modern: be like the fountain that my children and all my descendants flow from, has rejected me! Worse than that, she’s polluted herself, so that the fountain is a place where disgusting toads copulate and reproduce! Even the goddess of patience couldn’t look at this and be patient—it’s too horrifying!

original: I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.
modern: I hope you think I’m faithful to you.

original: Oh, ay, as summer flies are in the shambles, That quicken even with blowing. O thou weed, That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst ne'er been born!
modern: As faithful as flies in rotting meat, which give birth to maggots every time the wind blows. You’re like a weed pretending to be a flower, so beautiful and sweet-smelling that I ache when I look at you. Oh, I wish you’d never been born!

original: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?
modern: Have I done something to offend you without knowing it?

original: Was this fair paper, this most goodly book, Made to write “whore” upon? What committed? I should make very forges of my cheeks That would to cinders burn up modesty Did I but speak thy deeds. What committed? Heaven stops the nose at it and the moon winks, Is hushed within the hollow mine of earth And will not hear ’t. What committed! Impudent strumpet!
modern: Was someone as beautiful as you meant to be a whore? What have you done? What have you done? Oh, you streetwalker! If I said out loud what you’ve done, you’d burn up with shame. What have you done? Heaven has to hold its nose when it sees you! The pure moon in the sky has to shut its eyes when you go by! Even the wind that blows over everything on earth is ashamed to visit you. You brazen whore!

original: By heaven, you do me wrong!
modern: I swear to God you’re accusing me wrongly!

original: No, as I am a Christian. If to preserve this vessel for my lord From any other foul unlawful touch Be not to be a strumpet, I am none.
modern: No, I’m as honest as I am Christian. If only letting my husband touch my body means I’m not a whore, I’m not a whore.

original: No, as I shall be saved.
modern: No, I swear it.

original: Is ’t possible?
modern: Is that possible?

original: Oh, heaven forgive us!
modern: Oh, heaven help us!

original: I cry you mercy, then, I took you for that cunning whore of Venice That have the office opposite to Saint Peter And keep the gate of hell!
modern: I beg your pardon then. I must have the wrong woman. I mistook you for that sly Venetian woman who married Othello.—You whorehouse-keeper.

original: You, you, ay, you! We have done our course. There’s money for your pains. I pray you, turn the key and keep our counsel.
modern: You’re in charge of this hell! You! We’ve finished our business. Here’s some money for you. Please lock the door and keep quiet.

original: How do you, madam? How do you, my good lady?
modern: What’s he talking about? How are you, madam?

original: Faith, half asleep.
modern: I’m stunned, to tell you the truth.

original: Good madam, what’s the matter with my lord?
modern: My lady, what’s wrong with your husband?

original: With who?
modern: With who?

original: Why, with my lord, madam.
modern: Why, with your husband, madam. My lord.

original: He that is yours, sweet lady.
modern: My lord is your lord.

original: I have none. Do not talk to me, Emilia. I cannot weep, nor answers have I none, But what should go by water. Prithee, tonight Lay on my bed my wedding sheets. Remember,
modern: I don’t have a lord. Don’t talk to me, Emilia. I can’t even cry, though tears are the only answers I could give to all your questions. Tonight put my wedding sheets on my bed, and tell your husband to come to me now.

original: Here’s a change indeed!
modern: Things have certainly changed!

original: 'Tis meet I should be used so, very meet. How have I been behaved that he might stick The small’st opinion on my least misuse?
modern: It’s fair for him to treat me like this, very fair. What have I ever done that he has anything to complain about?

original: What is your pleasure, madam? How is ’t with you?
modern: What can I do for you, madam? How are you?

original: Do it with gentle means and easy tasks. He might have chid me so, for, in good faith, I am a child to chiding.
modern: I don’t know. When grown-ups teach little children, they do it gently and easily. He might have treated me like that, because I’m as unused to abuse as a little child.

original: What is the matter, lady?
modern: What’s the matter, lady?

original: Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhored her, That true hearts cannot bear it.
modern: He called her a whore so many times, and heaped up so much abuse on her that good people can’t stand to hear it.

original: Am I that name, Iago?
modern: Am I that name, Iago?

original: What name, fair lady?
modern: What name, madam?

original: Such as she says my lord did say I was.
modern: What my lord said I was.

original: Could not have laid such terms upon his callet.
modern: He called her a whore. A beggar couldn’t have called his slut worse names.

original: Why did he so?
modern: Why did he do that?

original: I do not know. I am sure I am none such.
modern: I don’t know. I just know I’m not one.

original: Do not weep, do not weep. Alas the day!
modern: Don’t cry, don’t cry. What a day this is!

original: Her father and her country, and her friends, To be called “whore”? Would it not make one weep?
modern: Did she give up all those chances to marry noblemen, give up her father and country and friends, just to be called a whore? Doesn’t that make you want to cry?

original: It is my wretched fortune.
modern: It’s just my bad luck.

original: Beshrew him for ’t! How comes this trick upon him?
modern: Damn him! How did he get such an idea?

original: Nay, heaven doth know.
modern: Heaven knows.

original: Some busy and insinuating rogue, Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office, Have not devised this slander. I will be hanged else!
modern: I bet my life some evil busybody, some meddling, lying jerk made up this rumor to get some position. I bet my life on it.

original: Fie, there is no such man. It is impossible.
modern: Nobody’s that bad. It’s impossible.

original: A halter pardon him and hell gnaw his bones! Why should he call her “whore”? Who keeps her company? What place? What time? What form? What likelihood? The Moor’s abused by some most villainous knave, O heavens, that such companions thou’dst unfold, And put in every honest hand a whip To lash the rascals naked through the world Even from the east to th' west!
modern: A hangman’s noose will help him! Let hell chew him up! Why should he call her a whore? Who’s been with her? When has she had the time, the place, or the means to sleep with anyone? How is this at all likely? The Moor is being tricked by some crook, some terrible villain, some rotten bastard. Oh, I wish we could unmask scoundrels like that, and give a whip to every good man to beat them senseless with!

original: Speak within door.
modern: Keep your voice down.

original: That turned your wit the seamy side without And made you to suspect me with the Moor.
modern: Oh, to hell with those people! It’s the same kind of guy who got you upset and made you suspect I’d cheated on you with the Moor.

original: You are a fool. Go to.
modern: You’re a fool. Shut up.

original: Alas Iago, What shall I do to win my lord again? I know not how I lost him. Here I kneel: If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love, Either in discourse of thought or actual deed, Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense, Or that I do not yet, and ever did,
modern: Oh God, Iago, what can I do to win my husband back again? Please go to him, my friend. I swear I have no idea why he stopped loving me. Here I’m kneeling to swear that if I ever did anything to destroy his love for me, either by thoughts or actions, or if I ever took pleasure in anyone else, or if I never did love him, or don’t love him now—even though he tries to shake me off—

original: And ever will—though he do shake me off To beggarly divorcement—love him dearly, Comfort forswear me! Unkindness may do much, But never taint my love. I cannot say “whore,” It does abhor me now I speak the word. To do the act that might the addition earn Not the world’s mass of vanity could make me.
modern: then I hope I have a life of misery! Unkindness is powerful, and his unkindness may kill me, but it’ll never destroy my love. I can’t say “whore.” It makes me sick to say the word even now. I wouldn’t do the thing that would make me a whore for all the money in the world.

original: The business of the state does him offence, And he does chide with you.
modern: Please calm down. He’s just in a bad mood. Political business is bothering him, and he’s just taking it out on you.

original: If ’twere no other—
modern: If only that were all it is—

original: 'Tis but so, I warrant.
modern: It is, I promise.

original: The messengers of Venice stays the meat. Go in, and weep not. All things shall be well.
modern: Those trumpets are calling us in to dinner. The Venetians are waiting for their food. Go in, and don’t cry. Everything will be all right.

original: How now, Roderigo!
modern: How are you, Roderigo?

original: I do not find that thou deal’st justly with me.
modern: I don’t think you’re treating me fairly.

original: Every day thou daff’st me with some device, Iago, and rather, as it seems to me now, keep’st from me all conveniency than suppliest me with the least advantage of hope.
modern: Every day you put me off with some trick. Instead of finding opportunities for me, you seem to be preventing me from making any progress.

original: I will indeed no longer endure it, nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace what already I have foolishly suffered.
modern: Well, I won’t take it any longer. And I’m not going to sit back and accept what you’ve done.

original: Will you hear me, Roderigo?
modern: Will you listen to me, Roderigo?

original: I have heard too much, and your words and performances are no kin together.
modern: I’ve listened to you too much already. Your words and actions don’t match up.

original: With naught but truth. I have wasted myself out of my means. The jewels you have had from me to deliver Desdemona would half have corrupted a votaress. You have told me she hath received them and returned me expectations and comforts of sudden respect and acquaintance, but I find none.
modern: It’s the truth. I’ve got no money left. The jewels you took from me to deliver to Desdemona would’ve made even a nun want to sleep with me. You told me she got them, and that she promised to give me a little something in return soon, but nothing like that ever happens.

original: Well, go to. Very well.
modern: Well, all right then. Fine.

original: “Very well,” “go to”! I cannot go to, man, nor ’tis not very well. Nay, I think it is scurvy, and begin to find myself fopped in it.
modern: “Fine!” he says. “All right!” It’s not fine, and I’m not all right! It’s wrong, and I’m starting to realize I’m being cheated!

original: Very well.
modern: Okay.

original: You have said now.
modern: You’ve said what you have to say now.

original: Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of doing.
modern: Yes, and I’ll do everything I just said.

original: Why, now I see there’s mettle in thee, and even from this instant to build on thee a better opinion than ever before. Give me thy hand, Roderigo. Thou hast taken against me a most just exception, but yet I protest I have dealt most directly in thy affair.
modern: Well, all right then. Now I see that you have some guts. From this moment on I have a higher opinion of you than before. Give me your hand, Roderigo. Your complaint against me is perfectly understandable, but I still insist I’ve done everything I could to help you.

original: It hath not appeared.
modern: It doesn’t look that way to me.

original: Well, what is it? Is it within reason and compass?
modern: Well, what’s your plan? Is it feasible?

original: Sir, there is especial commission come from Venice to depute Cassio in Othello’s place.
modern: Venice has made Cassio governor here on Cyprus.

original: Is that true? Why, then Othello and Desdemona return again to Venice.
modern: Is that true? Then Desdemona and Othello will go back to Venice.

original: Oh, no, he goes into Mauritania and taketh away with him the fair Desdemona, unless his abode be lingered here by some accident—wherein none can be so determinate as the removing of Cassio.
modern: Oh, no. He’ll go to Mauritania and take the beautiful Desdemona with him, unless he gets stuck here for some reason. The best way to extend his stay here is to get rid of Cassio.

original: Why, by making him uncapable of Othello’s place: knocking out his brains.
modern: I mean knock his brains out, so he can’t take Othello’s place.

original: And that you would have me to do!
modern: And that’s what you want me to do!

original: Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right. He sups tonight with a harlotry, and thither will I go to him. He knows not yet of his honorable fortune. If you will watch his going thence (which I will fashion to fall out between twelve and one) you may take him at your pleasure. I will be near to second your attempt, and he shall fall between us. Come, stand not amazed at it, but go along with me. I will show you such a necessity in his death that you shall think yourself bound to put it on him. It is now high suppertime, and the night grows to waste. About it!
modern: Yes, if you want to help yourself. He’s having dinner tonight with a prostitute, and I’ll go visit him. He doesn’t know he’s been appointed governor yet. When you see him walking by here (as I’ll make sure he does between twelve and one) you can nab him. I’ll be nearby to help you, and between the two of us we can handle him. Come on, don’t stand there in a daze. Come along with me. I’ll give you such reasons for killing him that you’ll feel obliged to snuff him out. It’s nearly dinner time, and the night’s going to be wasted. Let’s go!

original: I will hear further reason for this.
modern: I want to hear more about this.

original: I do beseech you, sir, trouble yourself no further.
modern: Please, sir, don’t trouble yourself.

original: Oh, pardon me, ’twill do me good to walk.
modern: I beg your pardon; walking will make me feel better.

original: Madam, good night. I humbly thank your ladyship.
modern: Good night, madam. Thank you.

original: Your honor is most welcome.
modern: You’re most welcome.

original: My lord?
modern: Yes, my lord?

original: Get you to bed on th' instant, I will be returned Forthwith. Dismiss your attendant there, look ’t be done.
modern: Go to bed right this minute. I’ll be there shortly. Send your maid Emilia away. Make sure you do what I say.

original: I will, my lord.
modern: I will, my lord.

original: He says he will return incontinent, And hath commanded me to go to bed And bid me to dismiss you.
modern: He says he’ll come back right away. He asked me to go to bed and to send you away.

original: Dismiss me?
modern: Send me away?

original: It was his bidding. Therefore, good Emilia, We must not now displease him.
modern: That’s what he said. So give me my nightgown, Emilia, and I’ll say goodnight. We shouldn’t displease him.

original: Ay. Would you had never seen him!
modern: Yes. I wish you’d never met him.

original: So would not I. My love doth so approve him That even his stubbornness, his checks, his frowns—
modern: That’s not what I wish. I love him even when he’s harsh and mean—Help me unpin this, would you?—I love even his stubbornness, his frowns, his bad moods.

original: I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.
modern: I put those wedding sheets on your bed, as you asked.

original: All’s one. Good Father, how foolish are our minds! If I do die before thee, prithee, shroud me In one of these same sheets.
modern: It doesn’t matter. Oh, how silly we are! If I die before you do make sure I’m wrapped in those sheets in my coffin.

original: Come, come! You talk!
modern: Listen to you! Don’t be silly!

original: She was in love, and he she loved proved mad And did forsake her. She had a song of “Willow,” An old thing ’twas, but it expressed her fortune And she died singing it. That song tonight But to go hang my head all at one side And sing it like poor Barbary. Prithee, dispatch.
modern: My mother had a maid named Barbary. She was in love, and her lover turned out to be wild and left her. She knew an old song called “Willow” that reminded her of her own story, and she died singing it. I can’t get that song out of my head tonight. It’s all I can do to keep myself from hanging my head down in despair and singing it like poor Barbary. Please, hurry up.

original: Shall I go fetch your nightgown?
modern: Should I get your nightgown?

original: No, unpin me here. This Lodovico is a proper man.
modern: No, just help me unpin this. That Lodovico is a good-looking man.

original: He speaks well.
modern: He speaks well.

original: I know a lady in Venice would have walked barefoot to Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.
modern: I know a lady in Venice who’d walk all the way to Palestine for a kiss from him.

original: (singing)  The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree,  Sing all a green willow.  Her hand on her bosom, her head on her knee,  Sing willow, willow, willow.  The fresh streams ran by her, and murmured her moans,  Sing willow, willow, willow.  Her salt tears fell from her, and softened the stones  Sing willow, willow, willow—  Lay by these—     Willow, willow—  Prithee, hie thee, he’ll come anon—  Sing all a green willow must be my garland.  Let nobody blame him, his scorn I approve— Nay, that’s not next—Hark! Who is ’t that knocks?
modern: (singing)  The poor soul sat singing by the sycamore tree,  Everyone sing the green willow,  She had her hand on her breast and her head on her knee,  Sing willow, willow, willow.  The fresh streams ran by her and murmured her moans,  Sing willow, willow, willow.  Her salt tears fell from her and softened the stones,  Sing willow, willow, willow.—  Put these things over there.—  Please, hurry, he’ll come right away.—  Everyone sing, a green willow must be my garland.  Nobody blame him, he’s right to hate me— No, that’s not how it goes.—Who’s knocking?

original: It’s the wind.
modern: It’s the wind.

original: I called my love false love but what said he then?   Sing willow, willow, willow. If I court more women you’ll couch with more men— So, get thee gone, good night. Mine eyes do itch, Doth that bode weeping?
modern: (singing) I told my lover he didn’t love me, but what did he say? Sing willow, willow, willow. If I chase more women, you’ll sleep with more men—Okay, go away now. Good night. My eyes itch—is that an omen I’ll be crying soon?

original: 'Tis neither here nor there.
modern: No, it doesn’t mean anything.

original: Dost thou in conscience think—tell me, Emilia— That there be women do abuse their husbands In such gross kind?
modern: I heard someone say that’s what it means. Oh, these men, these men! Do you honestly think—tell me, Emilia—there are women who’d cheat on their husbands in such a disgusting manner?

original: There be some such, no question.
modern: There are women like that out there, no question.

original: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
modern: Would you ever do such a thing for all the world?

original: No, by this heavenly light!
modern: By the light of heaven, no, I would not!

original: Nor I neither, by this heavenly light. I might do ’t as well i' th' dark.
modern: I wouldn’t either, by daylight. It would be easier to do it in the dark.

original: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?
modern: Could you really do such a thing, for all the world?

original: The world’s a huge thing. It is a great price for a small vice.
modern: The world’s huge. It’s a big prize for such a small sin.

original: In troth, I think I should, and undo ’t when I had done. Marry, I would not do such a thing for a joint-ring, nor for measures of lawn, nor for gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor any petty exhibition. But for the whole world? Why, who would not make her husband a cuckold to make him a monarch? I should venture purgatory for ’t.
modern: Actually I think I would, and then I’d undo it after I did it. I wouldn’t do it for a nice ring, or fine linen, or pretty gowns or petticoats or hats. But for the whole world? Who wouldn’t cheat on her husband to make him king? I’d risk my soul for that.

original: Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong For the whole world.
modern: I’d never do such a bad thing, not for the whole world!

original: Why the wrong is but a wrong i' th' world, and having the world for your labor, ’tis a wrong in your own world, and you might quickly make it right.
modern: Why, a bad action is just a wrong in this world, but when you’ve won the whole world, it’s a wrong in your own world, so you can make it right then.

original: Yes, a dozen, and as many to th' vantage as would store the world they played for. But I do think it is their husbands' faults If wives do fall. Say that they slack their duties
modern: Yes, a dozen of them—as many as there are women in the world, in fact. But I do think it’s the husband’s fault if we wives cheat on them. For instance, our husbands

original: And pour our treasures into foreign laps, Throwing restraint upon us. Or say they strike us, Or scant our former having in despite. Why, we have galls, and though we have some grace, Yet have we some revenge. Let husbands know And have their palates both for sweet and sour, As husbands have. What is it that they do When they change us for others? Is it sport? I think it is. And doth affection breed it? It is so too. And have not we affections, Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have? Then let them use us well, else let them know, The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.
modern: may stop sleeping with us, and give it out to other women instead. Or they may get insanely jealous, and keep us from going anywhere. Or let’s say they hit us, or cut back on the money they give us out of spite. We have feelings. We may be able to forgive them, but we want to get back at them too. Husbands need to know that their wives are human beings too. They see, smell, and taste sweet and sour just like their husbands. Why do they replace us with other women? Do they do it for fun? I think they do. Is it out of lust? I think so. Is it a weakness? It is. And don’t we have passions, and a taste for fun, and weaknesses, just like men? Then tell them to treat us well. Or let them figure out that the bad things we do are just what we learned from them.

original: Not to pick bad from bad, but by bad mend!
modern: Good night, good night. I pray that God will let me learn from women like that—not to follow their bad example, but to avoid it!

original: Here, stand behind this bulk, straight will he come. Wear thy good rapier bare, and put it home. Quick, quick! Fear nothing. I’ll be at thy elbow. It makes us, or it mars us. Think on that,
modern: Here, stand behind this wall; he’ll come right away. Keep your sword out, and then stick it in as far as it’ll go. Quick, quick. Don’t be afraid. I’ll be right next to you. This will either make us or break us. Keep that in mind, and be steady.

original: Be near at hand, I may miscarry in ’t.
modern: Stay right near me. I may mess it up.

original: Here, at thy hand. Be bold, and take thy stand.
modern: I’m right behind you. Be bold, and get ready.

original: I have no great devotion to the deed And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons.
modern: I don’t really want to do this, but he’s given me good reasons. I guess it’s only one man—no big deal. My sword comes out, and he dies.

original: (aside) I have rubbed this young quat almost to the sense, And he grows angry. Now, whether he kill Cassio Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other, Every way makes my gain. Live Roderigo, Of gold and jewels that I bobbed from him As gifts to Desdemona. It must not be. If Cassio do remain He hath a daily beauty in his life May unfold me to him—there stand I in much peril. No, he must die. But so, I hear him coming.
modern: (to himself) I’ve rubbed this young pimple until he’s ready to pop, and now he’s angry. Whether he kills Cassio, or Cassio kills him, or they kill each other, it all works in my favor. If Roderigo survives, though, he’ll ask me for all the gold and jewelry that I stole from him and said I gave to Desdemona. I can’t let that happen. If Cassio survives,he’s so handsome and well-spoken that he makes me look ugly. And besides, the Moor might tell him about my lies about him.—That would be very dangerous for me. No, he’s got to die. Let it be so. I hear him coming.

original: I know his gait, ’tis he.—Villain, thou diest!
modern: I know the sound of his walk.—Die, villain!

original: That thrust had been mine enemy indeed I will make proof of thine.
modern: That thrust might really have hurt me if I didn’t have this armor on under my cloak. Now let’s see what you’ve got on.

original: Oh, I am slain!
modern: Oh, I’m dead!

original: I am maimed for ever. Help, ho! Murder! Murder!
modern: I’ll be crippled forever! Help! Murder! murder!

original: The voice of Cassio. Iago keeps his word.
modern: That’s Cassio’s voice. Iago has kept his word.

original: Oh, villain that I am!
modern: Oh, what a villain I am!

original: Oh, help, ho! Light! A surgeon!
modern: Help me! Get some light! Get me a surgeon!

original: 'Tis he. Oh, brave Iago, honest and just, That hast such noble sense of thy friend’s wrong!
modern: It’s him! Brave Iago, how honest and trustworthy you are! You even went as far as murder to help your friend in his misfortune. You teach me how I should act.

original: Thou teachest me. Minion, your dear lies dead, For, of my heart, those charms, thine eyes, are blotted. Thy bed, lust-stained, shall with lust’s blood be spotted.
modern: Whore, your lover’s dead now, and you’ll be going to hell soon. I’m coming, slut! I’ve shut the memory of your beautiful eyes out of my heart. You’ve already stained our sheets with your lust; now I’ll stain them with your whore’s blood.

original: What, ho! No watch? No passage? Murder! Murder!
modern: Help! Isn’t there a guard around? No one passing by? Murder! Murder!

original: 'Tis some mischance, the cry is very direful.
modern: Something’s wrong, the man sounds panicked.

original: Hark!
modern: Listen!

original: Oh, wretched villain!
modern: I’ve acted like such a villain!

original: Two or three groan. 'Tis heavy night, These may be counterfeits. Let’s think ’t unsafe
modern: Two or three men are groaning. But it’s dark out, and it could be a trap. It’s not safe to go near them till we get more help.

original: Nobody come? Then shall I bleed to death.
modern: Nobody’s coming? I’ll bleed to death.

original: Hark!
modern: Look!

original: Here’s one comes in his shirt, with light and weapons.
modern: Here’s someone coming in his pajamas, with a candle and weapons.

original: Who’s there? Whose noise is this that ones on murder?
modern: Who’s there? Who’s shouting “murder”?

original: Do not you hear a cry?
modern: Didn’t you hear someone shouting?

original: Here, here! For heaven’s sake, help me!
modern: I’m here, here! For heaven’s sake, help me!

original: What’s the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

original: (to LODOVICO) This is Othello’s ancient, as I take it.
modern: (to LODOVICO) That’s Othello’s ensign, I think.

original: The same indeed, a very valiant fellow.
modern: It is. He’s a good man.

original: (to CASSIO) What are you here that cry so grievously?
modern: (to CASSIO) Who’s shouting so loudly?

original: Give me some help.
modern: Is that you, Iago? I’m here, I’ve been destroyed by villains! Help me.

original: Oh, me, lieutenant! What villains have done this?
modern: Oh, lieutenant! What villains did this to you?

original: I think that one of them is hereabout, And cannot make away.
modern: I think one of them is nearby and can’t get away.

original: Oh, treacherous villains!— What are you there? Come in, and give some help.
modern: The treacherous criminals!—(to LODOVICO and GRATIANO) Who’s there? Come here and help!

original: Oh, help me there!
modern: Somebody help me over here!

original: That’s one of them.
modern: That’s one of them.

original: O murd'rous slave! O villain!
modern: (to RODERIGO) Murderer! Villain!

original: O damned Iago! O inhuman dog!
modern: Damned Iago! You inhuman dog!

original: How silent is this town!—Ho! murder! murder!— What may you be? Are you of good or evil?
modern: Killing men in the dark? Where are these murderers? This is such a quiet, sleepy town!—Murder, murder!—Who’s that coming? Are you good or evil?

original: As you shall prove us, praise us.
modern: Judge for yourself.

original: Signior Lodovico?
modern: Signor Lodovico?

original: I cry you mercy. Here’s Cassio hurt by villains.
modern: I beg your pardon. Cassio’s been wounded.

original: Cassio!
modern: Cassio!

original: How is ’t, brother!
modern: How are you doing, brother?

original: My leg is cut in two.
modern: My leg’s been cut in two.

original: Light, gentlemen, I’ll bind it with my shirt.
modern: God forbid! Bring me some light, gentlemen, I’ll bind the wound with my shirt.

original: What is the matter, ho? Who is ’t that cried?
modern: What’s the matter? Who’s shouting?

original: Who is ’t that cried?
modern: Who’s shouting?

original: Oh, my dear Cassio! My sweet Cassio! O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
modern: Oh, my dear Cassio! My sweet Cassio! Oh, Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

original: Who they should be that have thus mangled you?
modern: You notorious whore! Cassio, do you know who might have stabbed you like this?

original: No.
modern: No.

original: I am sorry to find you thus. I have been to seek you.
modern: I’m sorry to find you like this. I’ve been looking all over for you.

original: Lend me a garter. So.—Oh, for a chair,
modern: Lend me your sash—Oh, if we only had a stretcher to carry him out of here!

original: Alas, he faints! O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
modern: He’s fainted! Oh Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

original: Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash To be a party in this injury.— Patience awhile, good Cassio.—Come, come, Alas, my friend and my dear countryman Roderigo! No—yes, sure! Yes, ’tis Roderigo.
modern: Sir, I believe this piece of trash, Bianca, has something to do with all this trouble.—Hang in there, Cassio.—Come here, bring the light. Do you recognize this face? Oh, no, it’s my friend and countryman, Roderigo.—Yes, it’s Roderigo!

original: What, of Venice?
modern: What, Roderigo from Venice?

original: Even he, sir. Did you know him?
modern: That’s the one, sir. Do you know him?

original: Signior Gratiano? I cry you gentle pardon, These bloody accidents must excuse my manners That so neglected you.
modern: Signor Gratiano, I beg your pardon. I didn’t mean to ignore you—it’s just because of this bloody uproar.

original: I am glad to see you.
modern: I’m glad to see you.

original: How do you, Cassio?—Oh, a chair, a chair!
modern: How are you doing, Cassio?—Someone bring me a stretcher!

original: He, he, ’tis he.
modern: It’s him, it’s him.

original: Oh, that’s well said—the chair! Some good man bear him carefully from hence. I’ll fetch the general’s surgeon.—(to BIANCA) For you, mistress, Save you your labor.—He that lies slain here, Cassio,
modern: Good—here’s the stretcher. Get somebody strong to carry him out of here. I’ll get the general’s surgeon. (to BIANCA) As for you, ma'am, don’t bother. The man lying here was my dear friend, Roderigo.—What was the problem between you?

original: None in the world, nor do I know the man.
modern: There wasn’t any problem. I don’t even know him.

original: (to BIANCA) What, look you pale?—Oh, bear him out o' the air.—
modern: (to BIANCA) You’re pale?—Get Cassio out of here.—You look awfully pale, Bianca.

original: Do you perceive the gastness of her eye?—Stay you, good gentlemen.—Look you pale, mistress?— Behold her well. I pray you, look upon her. Do you see, gentlemen? Nay, guiltiness Will speak, though tongues were out of use.
modern: Do you see how afraid she is? Watch her, we’ll get the whole story. Keep an eye on her. Do you see? The guilty speak volumes even when they’re silent.

original: Alas, what is the matter? What is the matter, husband?
modern: What’s the matter? What’s the matter, husband?

original: By Roderigo and fellows that are ’scaped. He’s almost slain, and Roderigo dead.
modern: Cassio was attacked here in the dark by Roderigo and men who escaped. He’s near death, and Roderigo’s dead already.

original: Alas, good gentleman! Alas, good Cassio!
modern: Oh, no, good gentleman! Oh no, good Cassio!

original: This is the fruits of whoring. Prithee, Emilia, (to BIANCA) What, do you shake at that?
modern: This is what happens when you visit whores. Please, Emilia, ask Cassio where he was at dinner tonight.—(to BIANCA) What, does that make you nervous?

original: He supped at my house, but I therefore shake not.
modern: He ate at my house, but that doesn’t make me nervous.

original: Oh, did he so? I charge you, go with me.
modern: Oh, did he? I order you to come with me.

original: Oh, fie upon thee, strumpet!
modern: Go to hell, you whore!

original: As you that thus abuse me.
modern: I’m no whore. I’m as moral as you are.

original: As I! Fie upon thee!
modern: As moral as me! Damn you!

original: Kind gentlemen, let’s go see poor Cassio dressed.— Come, mistress, you must tell ’s another tale. Emilia, run you to the citadel Will you go on afore? (aside)     This is the night That either makes me or fordoes me quite.
modern: Gentlemen, let’s go make sure Cassio’s wounds are properly dressed.—Come on, ma'am, you can tell us another story. Emilia, go to the castle and tell Othello and Desdemona what happened.—Will you please go now? (to himself) This is the night that’ll either make me or break me.

original: It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul. Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars, It is the cause. Yet I’ll not shed her blood, Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow Yet she must die, else she’ll betray more men. Put out the light, and then put out the light. If I quench thee, thou flaming minister, I can again thy former light restore Thou cunning’st pattern of excelling nature, I know not where is that Promethean heat That can thy light relume. When I have plucked thy rose I cannot give it vital growth again, Oh, balmy breath, that dost almost persuade Justice to break her sword! One more, one more. Be thus when thou art dead and I will kill thee And love thee after. (kissing her) One more, and that’s the last. But they are cruel tears. This sorrow’s heavenly, It strikes where it doth love. She wakes.
modern: I have to do it, I have to do it. I have to keep my reason in mind. I won’t say out loud what my reason is, but I have to do it. But I won’t shed any of her blood or scar that beautiful skin, whiter than snow and smooth as the finest marble. But she’s got to die, or she’ll cheat on other men. Put out the light of the candle, and then put out the light of her heart. If I extinguish the candle, I can light it again if I regret it. But once I kill you, you beautiful, fake woman, I do not know the magic that could bring you back. When I’ve plucked this rose, I can’t make it grow again; it will have no choice but to wither and die. Let me smell you while you’re still on the tree. (he kisses her) Oh, that sweet breath almost convinces me not to kill you and carry out justice. One more, one more kiss. If you’re this beautiful when you’re dead, I’ll kill you and then love you afterward. (kissing her) One more, and this is the last. Such a sweet kiss was never so deadly. I have to cry, but I have to be cruel too. I’m acting like God in the Old Testament—I have to punish the one I love. She’s waking up.

original: Who’s there? Othello?
modern: Who’s there? Othello?

original: Ay, Desdemona.
modern: Yes, Desdemona.

original: Have you prayed tonight, Desdemon?
modern: Have you said your prayers tonight, Desdemona?

original: Ay, my lord.
modern: Yes, my lord.

original: If you bethink yourself of any crime Unreconciled as yet to heaven and grace,
modern: If you can think of any crime you haven’t confessed, then pray for forgiveness right away.

original: Alack, my lord, what do you mean by that?
modern: Oh, my lord, what do you mean by that?

original: Well, do it, and be brief. I will walk by. I would not kill thy unpreparèd spirit. No, heavens forfend, I would not kill thy soul!
modern: Well, hurry up and confess. Be quick about it. I’ll wait over here. I don’t want to kill you before you’ve readied your soul. No, I don’t want to send your soul to hell when I kill you.

original: Ay, I do.
modern: Yes, I am.

original: Then heaven Have mercy on me!
modern: Then heaven have mercy on me.

original: Amen, with all my heart.
modern: Amen to that, from the bottom of my heart.

original: If you say, I hope you will not kill me.
modern: If you really feel that way, then I hope you won’t kill me.

original: Humh!
modern: Hmmph!

original: When your eyes roll so. Why I should fear I know not, Since guiltiness I know not. But yet I feel I fear.
modern: You’re scaring me. You terrify me when you have that look in your eyes. I don’t know why I should be afraid, since I haven’t done anything wrong. But I’m still afraid.

original: Think on thy sins.
modern: Think of your sins.

original: They are loves I bear to you.
modern: My only sin was loving you too much.

original: That death’s unnatural that kills for loving. Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip? Some bloody passion shakes your very frame. These are portents, but yet I hope, I hope
modern: You’re wrong to kill me for loving you. Why are you chewing on your lower lip like that? You’re shaking with emotion. These are bad omens, but I hope, I hope, they don’t predict my future.

original: Peace, and be still.
modern: Quiet. Stay still.

original: I will so. What’s the matter?
modern: I will. What’s this all about?

original: That handkerchief Which I so loved and gave thee, thou gav’st To Cassio.
modern: You gave that handkerchief, the one I loved and gave to you, to Cassio.

original: Send for the man and ask him.
modern: No, I swear by my life and soul! Bring him here and ask him.

original: Sweet soul, take heed, take heed of perjury. Thou art on thy deathbed.
modern: My sweet darling, don’t lie. You’re on your deathbed.

original: Ay—but not yet to die!
modern: I am? But I’m not dying yet!

original: Therefore confess thee freely of thy sin, For to deny each article with oath Cannot remove nor choke the strong conception That I do groan withal. Thou art to die.
modern: Yes, right now. So confess your sin freely now. Even if you swear you’re innocent of every accusation, you won’t change my mind or remove the thought that’s tormenting me. You’re going to die.

original: I say “amen.”
modern: Amen to that.

original: And have you mercy too! I never did Offend you in my life, never loved Cassio But with such general warranty of heaven As I might love. I never gave him token.
modern: And you have mercy on me too! I never did anything wrong to you in my life. I never loved Cassio, except with the pure love that I feel for humankind. I never gave him any token of romantic love.

original: O perjured woman, thou dost stone my heart, And mak’st me call what I intend to do A murder, which I thought a sacrifice! I saw the handkerchief.
modern: I saw him holding the handkerchief! You liar, you’re turning my heart to stone, and making me call what I’ll do murder, when I had been thinking of it as a sacrifice! I saw the handkerchief.

original: He found it then, Let him confess a truth.
modern: He found it somewhere, then. I never gave it to him. Tell him to come here. He’ll tell the truth.

original: He hath confessed.
modern: He’s already done so.

original: What, my lord?
modern: What, my lord?

original: That he hath usèd thee.
modern: That he had sex with you.

original: How? Unlawfully?
modern: What? Had sex with me?

original: Ay.
modern: Yes.

original: No, his mouth is stopped. Honest Iago Hath ta'en order for ’t.
modern: No. He won’t say anything anymore. Honest Iago’s arranged that.

original: Oh! My fear interprets. What, is he dead?
modern: Oh, I’m scared. What, is he dead?

original: Had all his hairs been lives
modern: If he had as many lives as he’s got hairs on his head, I would’ve killed them all in revenge.

original: Alas, he is betrayed and I undone.
modern: Oh, he’s been betrayed, and I’ve been ruined.

original: Out, strumpet! weep’st thou for him to my face?
modern: What, you whore, are you crying for him right in front of me?

original: Oh, banish me, my lord, but kill me not!
modern: Send me away, my lord, but don’t kill me!

original: Down, strumpet!
modern:
Down
Othello probably wrestles her down.

Down, whore!

original: Nay, if you strive—
modern: No, if you struggle with me—

original: But half an hour!
modern: Just half an hour!

original: Being done, there is no pause.
modern: While I’m doing this, I can’t pause for a moment.

original: But while I say one prayer!
modern: Just let me say one prayer!

original: (within) My lord , my lord! What, ho! My lord, my lord!
modern: (offstage) My lord, my lord! Hello! My lord, my lord!

original: What noise is this?—Not dead? Not yet quite dead? I that am cruel am yet merciful, I would not have thee linger in thy pain.
modern: What’s that noise? Aren’t you dead yet? I know I’m cruel, but I’m merciful too. I don’t want you to linger in pain.

original: (within) What, ho! My lord, my lord!
modern: (offstage) Hello! My lord, my lord!

original: Who’s there?
modern: Who’s there?

original: (within) O good my lord, I would speak a word with you!
modern: (offstage) Oh my lord, I need to speak to you!

original: Yes, ’tis Emilia.—(to EMILIA) By and by.—She’s dead.— 'Tis like she comes to speak of Cassio’s death, Still as the grave. Shall she come in? Were ’t good? I think she stirs again—No. What’s best to do? If she come in, she’ll sure speak to my wife— My wife! my wife! what wife? I have no wife. Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse Of sun and moon, and that th' affrighted globe Should yawn at alteration.
modern: Yes, it’s Emilia.(to EMILIA)—Just a minute!—She’s dead now.—Emilia’s probably come to tell me that Cassio’s been killed. The fight outside was loud. So! You’re not moving anymore? No, you’re as still as a grave. Should I let her in? Is that a good idea? I think she’s moving again—No. What should I do? If she comes in, she’ll try to speak to my wife. My wife, my wife! What wife? I don’t have a wife. Oh, this is unbearable! Oh, the horror! There should be a huge eclipse of the sun and the moon, now that Desdemona’s no longer on this earth.

original: (within) I do beseech you
modern: (offstage) Please, my lord. I need to speak with you. Oh, my good lord!

original: I had forgot thee—Oh, come in, Emilia. Soft, by and by. Let me the curtains draw. Where art thou?
modern: I’d forgotten about you—Emilia, wait a moment, let me draw the curtains. (closes the bed curtains) Where are you? (unlocks the door)

original: What’s the matter with thee now?
modern: What’s the matter with you now?

original: O my good lord, yonder’s foul murders done!
modern: Oh, my lord, terrible murders have been committed over there!

original: But now, my lord.
modern: Yes, just now, my lord.

original: It is the very error of the moon, She comes more nearer earth than she was wont And makes men mad.
modern: It’s because of the full moon. It comes too close to the earth and drives men crazy.

original: Called Roderigo.
modern: Cassio’s killed a young Venetian named Roderigo.

original: Roderigo killed? And Cassio killed!
modern: Roderigo’s been killed? And Cassio’s killed?

original: No, Cassio is not killed.
modern: No, Cassio wasn’t killed.

original: Not Cassio killed! Then murder’s out of tune, And sweet revenge grows harsh.
modern: Cassio’s not dead? Then the wrong man is dead, and sweet revenge has gone wrong.

original: Alas, what cry is that?
modern: Oh Lord, who’s that crying?

original: That? What?
modern: That? What?

original: Out and alas, that was my lady’s voice.
modern: Oh, no, that was my lady’s voice.

original: Help! Help, ho, help! O lady, speak again!
modern: Help! Help! Oh, lady, speak again. Sweet Desdemona! Oh sweet mistress, speak!

original: A guiltless death I die.
