modern: I’m dying an innocent woman.

original: Oh, who hath done this deed?
modern: Oh, who did this thing?

original: Nobody. I myself. Farewell. Commend me to my kind lord. Oh, farewell!
modern: No one. I did it myself. Give my love to my kind husband. Oh, goodbye!

original: Why, how should she be murdered?
modern: Why, how could she have been murdered?

original: Alas, who knows?
modern: My God, who knows?

original: She said so. I must needs report the truth.
modern: Yes, she said that. I must go report what happened.

original: She’s like a liar gone to burning hell. 'Twas I that killed her.
modern: She was lying even as she was going down to hell. I did kill her.

original: Oh, the more angel she,
modern: Then she was even more an angel, and you’re an even blacker devil!

original: She turned to folly, and she was a whore.
modern: She cheated on me, and she was a whore.

original: Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil.
modern: You slander her, you devil.

original: She was false as water.
modern: She was fickle and unfaithful, like water.

original: Thou art rash as fire, To say that she was false. Oh, she was heavenly true!
modern: You’ve lost your mind to accuse her of cheating. She was utterly true to you!

original: Oh, I were damned beneath all depth in hell, But that I did proceed upon just grounds To this extremity. Thy husband knew it all.
modern: Cassio had sex with her. Ask your husband if you doubt me. If I didn’t have a good reason to do this, damn me to the very bottom of hell. Your husband knew about everything.

original: My husband!
modern: My husband!

original: Thy husband.
modern: Your husband.

original: That she was false to wedlock?
modern: He said she was unfaithful?

original: If heaven would make me such another world Of one entire and perfect chrysolite, I’d not have sold her for it.
modern: Yes, with Cassio. If she’d been faithful to me, I never would have given her up, not even if God himself offered me a jewel as big as a planet in exchange for her.

original: My husband?
modern: My husband.

original: Ay, ’twas he that told me on her first. That sticks on filthy deeds.
modern: Yes, he’s the one who first told me about her. He’s an honest man who detests evil actions.

original: My husband!
modern: My husband?

original: What needs this iterance, woman? I say thy husband.
modern: Why do you keep repeating that, woman? I’m telling you, your husband.

original: O mistress, villainy hath made mocks with love! My husband say that she was false!
modern: Oh, my mistress, a villain has made a mockery of your love! My husband said she was unfaithful!

original: He, woman. My friend, thy husband, honest, honest Iago.
modern: Yes, him, woman. I said “your husband.”—Do you understand that word? My friend, your husband, the honest, honest Iago.

original: If he say so, may his pernicious soul Rot half a grain a day! He lies to th' heart. She was too fond of her most filthy bargain.
modern: If he said that, then I hope his malicious soul rots in hell forever. He’s lying through his teeth! She was too attached to her filthy marriage ever to do a thing like that!

original: Do thy worst. This deed of thine is no more worthy heaven Than thou wast worthy her.
modern: Go ahead, do your worst. Killing me won’t send you to heaven. You weren’t good enough for her.

original: Peace, you were best.
modern: You’d better shut up!

original: Thou hast not half that power to do me harm As ignorant as dirt! Thou hast done a deed— I care not for thy sword, I’ll make thee known
modern: I can endure far more pain than you could ever give me! Oh, you idiot! You stupid fool! As dumb as dirt! You’ve committed a terrible evil—I’m not afraid of your sword. I’ll tell everyone what you did, even if it

original: Though I lost twenty lives.—Help! Help, ho! Help! The Moor hath killed my mistress! Murder, murder!
modern: costs me my life twenty times over.—Help, help, help! The Moor’s killed my mistress! Murder, murder!

original: Oh, are you come, Iago? You have done well, That men must lay their murders on your neck.
modern: Oh, are you here, Iago? You’ve done a good job, that other men can attribute their murders to you!

original: What is the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

original: (to IAGO) Disprove this villain, if thou be’st a man. I know thou didst not, thou'rt not such a villain. Speak, for my heart is full.
modern: (to IAGO) Tell this villain he’s wrong, if you’re man enough. He says you told him his wife cheated on him. I know you didn’t. You’re not that much of a villain. Speak, because I’m too emotional to say any more.

original: I told him what I thought, and told no more Than what he found himself was apt and true.
modern: I told him what I thought. I didn’t tell him anything that didn’t make sense or ring true to him.

original: I did.
modern: I did.

original: You told a lie, an odious, damnèd lie. Upon my soul, a lie, a wicked lie. She false with Cassio! Did you say with Cassio?
modern: Then you told a lie, a sick, wicked lie. I swear on my soul it was a lie. You said she slept with Cassio. Did you say Cassio?

original: I will not charm my tongue, I am bound to speak. My mistress here lies murdered in her bed—
modern: I will not be quiet! I have to speak. My mistress here lies murdered in her bed—

original: Oh, heavens forfend!
modern: No, heaven forbid!

original: And your reports have set the murder on.
modern: And your lies caused this murder.

original: 'Tis a strange truth.
modern: It may be true, but it’s unbelievable.

original: Oh, monstrous act!
modern: Oh, what a horrible deed!

original: Villainy, villainy, villainy! I think upon ’t, I think I smell ’t, Oh, villainy! I thought so then, I’ll kill myself for grief.
modern: Evil, evil, evil! I can smell it! I suspected it earlier. I’ll kill myself out of grief! Oh, evil, evil!

original: What, are you mad? I charge you, get you home.
modern: Are you crazy? I’m ordering you, go home.

original: Good gentlemen, let me have leave to speak. 'Tis proper I obey him, but not now. Perchance, Iago, I will ne'er go home.
modern: Good gentlemen, give me permission to speak. I know I ought to obey my husband, but not now. Maybe I’ll never go home again, Iago!

original: Nay, lay thee down and roar, For thou hast killed the sweetest innocent That e'er did lift up eye.
modern: Yes, go ahead and moan, because you killed the sweetest, most innocent woman who ever lived!

original: Oh, she was foul!— I scarce did know you, uncle. There lies your niece, Whose breath, indeed, these hands have newly stopped.
modern:
She was filthy! I barely knew you, Uncle 

Gratiano
Gratiano is Brabantio’s brother and Desdemona’s uncle.

Gratiano. Here’s your niece lying here dead. I killed her with these hands. I know this looks horrible.

original: Poor Desdemon! I am glad thy father’s dead, Thy match was mortal to him, and pure grief Shore his old thread in twain. Did he live now,
modern: Poor Desdemona! I’m glad your father isn’t alive to see this. Your marriage made him die of grief before his time. If he was alive now, this sight would hurt

original: This sight would make him do a desperate turn, And fall to reprobation.
modern: him terribly. It would make him curse the heavens and be damned to hell.

original: 'Tis pitiful, but yet Iago knows That she with Cassio hath the act of shame A thousand times committed. Cassio confessed it, With that recognizance and pledge of love Which I first gave her. I saw it in his hand, It was a handkerchief, an antique token My father gave my mother.
modern: It’s sad, but Iago knows she had sex with Cassio a thousand times. Cassio confessed it, and she pledged her love to him by giving him the handkerchief I’d given her. I saw it in his hand. It was an old memento that my father gave to my mother.

original: Oh, heaven! Oh, heavenly powers!
modern: Oh, God! Dear God in heaven!

original: 'Twill out, ’twill out.—I peace? No, I will speak as liberal as the north. Let heaven and men and devils, let them all, All, all cry shame against me, yet I’ll speak.
modern: No, the truth will come out—Me, shut my mouth? Let heaven and men and devils tell me to shut me up. I’ll say what I have to say.

original: I will not.
modern: I won’t.

original: Fie! Your sword upon a woman?
modern: Shame on you! Drawing your sword on a woman?

original: O thou dull Moor! That handkerchief thou speak’st of I found by fortune and did give my husband. More than indeed belonged to such a trifle— He begged of me to steal it.
modern: Oh, you stupid Moor! I found that handkerchief by accident and gave it to my husband. He’d begged me to steal it many times.

original: Villainous whore!
modern: You evil whore!

original: She give it Cassio? No, alas, I found it And I did give ’t my husband.
modern: You think she gave it to Cassio? No, I found it and gave it to my husband.

original: Filth, thou liest!
modern: You piece of filth, you’re lying!

original: (to OTHELLO) O murderous coxcomb! What should such a fool Do with so good a wife?
modern: I swear I’m not lying. (to OTHELLO) Oh, you murderous fool! How did you ever get such a good wife?

original: Are there no stones in heaven But what serve for the thunder?—Precious villain!
modern: Won’t heaven strike this Iago dead? You absolute villain!

original: Ay, ay. Oh, lay me by my mistress' side.
modern: Yes, yes! Lay me next to my mistress.

original: He’s gone, but his wife’s killed.
modern: He’s gone, and his wife’s dead.

original: 'Tis a notorious villain. Take you this weapon, Which I have recovered from the Moor. But kill him rather. I’ll after that same villain, For ’tis a damnèd slave.
modern: He’s a wicked, horrible criminal. Take the Moor’s sword and guard the door from the outside. Kill him rather than let him leave this room. I’m going after Iago. He’s a horrid criminal.

original: I am not valiant neither, But ever puny whipster gets my sword. But why should honor outlive honesty?
modern: I’m not that strong, if a puny nobody can grab my sword. But why should my reputation for honor last longer than my honor did? Let it all go.

original: What did thy song bode, lady? Hark, canst thou hear me? I will play the swan. And die in music. (singing) Willow, willow, willow— Moor, she was chaste, she loved thee, cruel Moor. So come my soul to bliss, as I speak true.
modern: What did your song mean, lady? Can you hear me? I’ll die like a swan. They sing when they die. (singing) Willow, willow, willow.— Moor, she never cheated on you. She loved you, you cruel man. I swear on my soul I’m telling the truth, and as I say this, I die.

original: I have another weapon in this chamber, It was a sword of Spain, the ice-brook’s temper. Oh, here it is. Uncle, I must come forth.
modern: I’ve got another weapon in the room. It’s a Spanish sword, hardened in ice cold water and razor sharp. Here it is. Uncle, I’m coming out!

original: (within) If thou attempt it, it will cost thee dear.
modern: (offstage) If you try that, you’ll pay for it. You’ve got no weapon, so you’ll have to suffer.

original: Look in upon me then and speak with me, Or, naked as I am, I will assault thee.
modern: Look in on me, and talk with me, or I’ll attack even without a weapon.

original: What is the matter?
modern: What’s the matter?

original: Behold, I have a weapon. A better never did itself sustain
modern: Look, I have a weapon, the best sword a soldier could have. I’ve fought my way through obstacles twenty times more terrifying than you with this weapon. But

original: That with this little arm and this good sword I have made my way through more impediments Than twenty times your stop. But, oh, vain boast! Who can control his fate? ’tis not so now. Here is my journey’s end, here is my butt, And very sea-mark of my utmost sail. Do you go back dismayed? ’tis a lost fear. Man but a rush against Othello’s breast, Now, how dost thou look now? O ill-starred wench, Pale as thy smock! When we shall meet at compt This look of thine will hurl my soul from heaven And fiends will snatch at it. Cold, cold, my girl, Whip me, ye devils, From the possession of this heavenly sight! Blow me about in winds, roast me in sulfur, Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire!—
modern: who can control his fate? I’m not like that now. Don’t be afraid, even though you see me with a weapon. This is the end of my journey, the end of my life. Are you backing away in fear? There’s no reason to be afraid. You could tap me with a feather and I’d back away. Where would Othello go?—Oh, look at you! Such cruel luck! You’re as pale as your nightgown! When we meet on Judgment Day, that look of yours will send me from heaven to hell, where devils will grab me. You’re cold, cold, and you were never hot with lust. Oh you damned villain! Whip me, you devils, so I don’t have to look at this heavenly sight! Blow on me with hot winds, roast me in lava, drown me in liquid fire! Oh, Desdemona! Dead Desdemona! Oh, oh!

original: Where is this rash and most unfortunate man?
modern: Where is that poor rash man?

original: That’s he that was Othello. Here I am.
modern: You mean the man who used to be Othello? Here I am.

original: Where is that viper? Bring the villain forth.
modern: Where’s that snake? Bring the villain forward.

original: I look down towards his feet, but that’s a fable.
modern: I’m looking to see if you have cloven hooves like the devil. But that’s just a fairy tale. If you are a devil, I won’t be able to kill you.

original: Wrench his sword from him.
modern: Take his sword away from him.

original: I bleed, sir, but not killed.
modern: I’m bleeding, but you didn’t kill me.

original: I am not sorry neither. I’d have thee live, For in my sense ’tis happiness to die.
modern: I’m not sorry, either. I want you to live, since to me, death is happiness.

original: O thou Othello, thou was once so good, What shall be said to thee?
modern: Oh Othello, you were once so good, then you were tricked by this villain. What can I say to you?

original: Why, anything. An honorable murderer, if you will, For naught I did in hate, but all in honor.
modern: Say anything. Call me an honorable murderer if you like. I did nothing out of hate, only out of honor.

original: This wretch hath part confessed his villainy.
modern: This poor guy’s partly confessed his plan. Did you plan Cassio’s death with him?

original: Ay.
modern: Yes.

original: Dear general, I never gave you cause.
modern: Dear general, I never gave you any reason to hate me.

original: I do believe it, and I ask your pardon. Will you, I pray, demand that demi-devil
modern: I believe you, and I ask you to forgive me. Will you please make this half-devil say why he tricked me and damned my soul?

original: Demand me nothing. What you know, you know. From this time forth I never will speak word.
modern: Don’t ask me anything. You know what you know. From this moment on, I’ll never say another word.

original: What, not to pray?
modern: What, not even to pray?

original: Torments will ope your lips.
modern: Torture will make you talk.

original: Sir, you shall understand what hath befall'n, Which, as I think, you know not. Here is a letter Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo, And here another. The one of them imports By Roderigo.
modern: Sir, you’ll understand everything that has happened. I don’t think you know now. Here is a letter we found in Roderigo’s pocket. And here’s another. This one talks about how Roderigo should kill Cassio.

original: Oh, villain!
modern: Oh, you villain!

original: Most heathenish and most gross!
modern: Ungodly and monstrous!

original: Now here’s another discontented paper Roderigo meant to have sent this damnèd villain But that, belike, Iago in the interim Came in and satisfied him.
modern: Here’s another letter from his pocket, addressed to Iago and full of complaints. We think he was going to send it to Iago, but then Iago stepped in and answered his complaints by killing him.

original: O thou pernicious caitiff! That was my wife’s?
modern: Oh, you wicked scoundrel! Cassio, how did you get my wife’s handkerchief?

original: I found it in my chamber, And he himself confessed but even now That there he dropped it for a special purpose Which wrought to his desire.
modern: I found it in my room, and Iago just confessed that he put it there for his own purposes.

original: O fool! fool! fool!
modern: Oh, what a fool I am!

original: How he upbraids Iago, that he made him Brave me upon the watch, whereon it came That I was cast. And even but now he spake, After long seeming dead—Iago hurt him,
modern: Also, in his letter to Iago, Roderigo criticizes Iago for telling him to get me angry while I was on guard duty, and get me demoted. And just now he admitted it, even though he’d seemed to be dead for a long while—Iago tricked him, Iago urged him to do it.

original: (to OTHELLO) You must forsake this room and go with us. Your power and your command is taken off And Cassio rules in Cyprus. For this slave, If there be any cunning cruelty It shall be his. You shall close prisoner rest Till that the nature of your fault be known To the Venetian state.—Come, bring him away.
modern: (to OTHELLO) You’ll have to leave this room and come with us. You’re stripped of your power and your command, and Cassio will govern Cyprus. As for this slave, Iago, if we can think of any torture that will hurt him a lot but keep him alive a long time, he’ll have it. You’ll remain a prisoner until we bring your crimes to the Venetian government.—Okay, take him away.

original: Soft you, a word or two before you go. No more of that. I pray you, in your letters, When you shall these unlucky deeds relate, Speak of me as I am. Nothing extenuate, Nor set down aught in malice. Then must you speak Of one not easily jealous, but being wrought, Perplexed in the extreme. Of one whose hand, Like the base Indian, threw a pearl away Richer than all his tribe. Of one whose subdued eyes, Drop tears as fast as the Arabian trees Their medicinal gum. Set you down this,
modern: Wait. A word or two before you go. I’ve given the state of Venice a bit of help in the past, and they know it. But enough about that. When you record these sad events in your letters, please describe me exactly as I am. Don’t tone things down or exaggerate them out of hostility. If you’re being fair, you’ll have to describe me as someone who loved too much, but who wasn’t wise about it. I was not easily made jealous, but once I was tricked and manipulated, I worked myself into a frenzy. Describe me as a fool who threw away a precious pearl with his own hands, like a silly Indian who didn’t know what it was worth. As someone who was not emotional, but who then cried a lot. Write all this

original: And say besides that in Aleppo once, Where a malignant and a turbaned Turk I took by the throat the circumcisèd dog, And smote him, thus.
modern: down, and then say also that in Aleppo I once saw a Turk beating a Venetian, so I grabbed the Turk by the throat and hit him like this.

original: Oh, bloody period!
modern: Oh, what a bloody end to all this!

original: All that is spoke is marred.
modern: Everything we’ve heard is bad.

original: I kissed thee ere I killed thee. No way but this, Killing myself, to die upon a kiss.
modern: (to DESDEMONA) I kissed you before I killed you. Now, killing myself, I’m dying while I kiss you again.

original: This did I fear, but thought he had no weapon, For he was great of heart.
modern: I was afraid this would happen, because he was a noble, brave man, but I didn’t think he had a weapon.

original: More fell than anguish, hunger, or the sea, Look on the tragic loading of this bed. This is thy work. The object poisons sight, Let it be hid.—Gratiano, keep the house For they succeed on you.—To you, lord governor, Remains the censure of this hellish villain: The time, the place, the torture. Oh, enforce it! Myself will straight aboard, and to the state
modern: (to IAGO) You bloodthirsty dog, you’re crueler than sadness or hunger, crueler than the sea. Look at these dead people on this bed. You did all this. He makes me sick. Take him away. Gratiano, take care of the house, and take the Moor’s property. You’ve inherited everything.—(to CASSIO) Governor, I leave it in your hands to punish this evil villain: just decide the time, the place and the means of torture. And then carry it out! I have to go back to Venice, and tell them about these sad events.
